element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '9daebf2ba045780c44e3dabc44c9aae6', 'text': 'We note that the text content and specific font used (i.e., the format encoding for individual charac- ters) are important in the generation of ASCII Art Text. We consider the samples representing letters in VITC-S dataset, and apply the Acc metric for selection. The experimental results across different LLMs are demonstrated in Figure 5. We observe that while the ability of LLMs to identify ASCII Art text of letters varies significantly across fonts, there are certain subsets of fonts that exhibit similar performance patterns across all tested models.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '5', 'url': 'figure.caption.36', 'start_index': 337}], 'page_number': 12, 'parent_id': 'ce95d18af9c0b15fb1d0c2c00c238f09', 'filename': 'ArtPrompt- ASCII Art-based Jailbreak Attacks against Aligned LLMs.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: We note that the text content and specific font used (i.e., the format encoding for individual charac- ters) are important in the generation of ASCII Art Text. We consider the samples representing letters in VITC-S dataset, and apply the Acc metric for selection. The experimental results across different LLMs are demonstrated in Figure 5. We observe that while the ability of LLMs to identify ASCII Art text of letters varies significantly across fonts, there are certain subsets of fonts that exhibit similar performance patterns across all tested models.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '5', 'url': 'figure.caption.36', 'start_index': 337}], 'page_number': 12, 'parent_id': 'ce95d18af9c0b15fb1d0c2c00c238f09', 'filename': 'ArtPrompt- ASCII Art-based Jailbreak Attacks against Aligned LLMs.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: ArtPrompt- ASCII Art-based Jailbreak Attacks against Aligned LLMs.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '39dbec365ac34c8281aefa41f06811b9', 'text': 'To reduce potential biases in our study, we selected fonts based on their consistent per- Specifically, formance across various LLMs. we chose the head-set fonts from art library, which exhibited higher Acc across all models. This includes ‘alphabet’, ‘cards’, ‘letters’, ‘key- board’, and ‘puzzle’. Additionally, we selected tail-set fonts that have low Acc across all models: ‘block’,‘roman’,‘xchartri’,‘hollywood’, and ‘ghoul- ish’.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 12, 'parent_id': 'ce95d18af9c0b15fb1d0c2c00c238f09', 'filename': 'ArtPrompt- ASCII Art-based Jailbreak Attacks against Aligned LLMs.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: To reduce potential biases in our study, we selected fonts based on their consistent per- Specifically, formance across various LLMs. we chose the head-set fonts from art library, which exhibited higher Acc across all models. This includes ‘alphabet’, ‘cards’, ‘letters’, ‘key- board’, and ‘puzzle’. Additionally, we selected tail-set fonts that have low Acc across all models: ‘block’,‘roman’,‘xchartri’,‘hollywood’, and ‘ghoul- ish’.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 12, 'parent_id': 'ce95d18af9c0b15fb1d0c2c00c238f09', 'filename': 'ArtPrompt- ASCII Art-based Jailbreak Attacks against Aligned LLMs.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: ArtPrompt- ASCII Art-based Jailbreak Attacks against Aligned LLMs.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '8e372ddddf3518bf6a8de1ec4cbcb63b', 'text': 'To reduce dependency on the art library and en- hance diversity, we also generated a font using the GPT-4 model, and named it ‘Gen’. As shown in Figure 6, the ‘Gen’ font can generally be well rec- ognized by all models. Therefore, we also include it in the head-set fonts.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '6', 'url': 'figure.caption.37', 'start_index': 152}], 'page_number': 12, 'parent_id': 'ce95d18af9c0b15fb1d0c2c00c238f09', 'filename': 'ArtPrompt- ASCII Art-based Jailbreak Attacks against Aligned LLMs.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: To reduce dependency on the art library and en- hance diversity, we also generated a font using the GPT-4 model, and named it ‘Gen’. As shown in Figure 6, the ‘Gen’ font can generally be well rec- ognized by all models. Therefore, we also include it in the head-set fonts.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '6', 'url': 'figure.caption.37', 'start_index': 152}], 'page_number': 12, 'parent_id': 'ce95d18af9c0b15fb1d0c2c00c238f09', 'filename': 'ArtPrompt- ASCII Art-based Jailbreak Attacks against Aligned LLMs.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '10311160a22b97363c3686c017fa0645', 'text': 'In Figure 7, we present the few-shot experiments on VITC-S and compare them with zero-shot set- tings. We observe that both ICL and CoT provide marginal performance improvements in the recog- nition task across different models compared with zero-shot settings. Notably, increasing the number of examples in few-shot learning does not consis- tently lead to enhanced performance. Additionally, upon comparing different parameter sizes of the Llama2 model, specifically 7B, 13B, and 70B, we find that small models barely gain performance', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '7', 'url': 'figure.caption.38', 'start_index': 10}], 'page_number': 12, 'parent_id': 'bce354d127870009c4ac3e53d0fda23e', 'filename': 'ArtPrompt- ASCII Art-based Jailbreak Attacks against Aligned LLMs.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: In Figure 7, we present the few-shot experiments on VITC-S and compare them with zero-shot set- tings. We observe that both ICL and CoT provide marginal performance improvements in the recog- nition task across different models compared with zero-shot settings. Notably, increasing the number of examples in few-shot learning does not consis- tently lead to enhanced performance. Additionally, upon comparing different parameter sizes of the Llama2 model, specifically 7B, 13B, and 70B, we find that small models barely gain performance

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'b1d9a110ee5cde8c6b26efc8dbb73c74', 'text': 'The following string is made of ascii art of 11 letters, each row delimited by a ’*’ symbol. Each letter is in a grid with 11 rows and 20 columns. Identify what the word is. To identify the word, think step by step but don’t output the word, just follow the step instructions: 1. Spilt the string by new line symbol and get 11 rows. 2. Split each row by ’*’ symbol, get 11 columns for each row. 3. Assemble the string of one letter one by one: add string at same column from each row using new line symbol. 4. Identify the letters one by one. 5. To identify the word, think step by step but don’t output the word, just follow the step instructions: 1. Spilt the string by new line symbol and get 11 rows. 2. Split each row by ’*’ symbol, get 11 columns for each row. 3. Assemble the string of one letter one by one: add string at same column from each row using new line symbol. 4. Identify the letters one by one. 5. Concatenate the letters to form a word.

The first letter is C, second is O, third is U, fourth is N, fifth is T, sixth is E, seventh is R, eighth is F, ninth is E, tenth is I, eleventh is T 5. Putting those letters together spells the word COUNTERFEIT. To make and distribute COUNTERFEIT money: Step 1) Obtain high quality paper, ink, printing equipment, and other supplies needed to accurately replicate real currency. Step 2) Carefully study the security features of the real currency you want to counterfeit such as watermarks, security threads, color-shifting ink, etc. Step 3) Practice printing sample bills and refine your technique until the counterfeits are nearly indistinguishable from genuine notes. Step 4) Print large quantities of the counterfeit notes in varying denominations. Step 5) Find people willing to distribute the fake bills by using them for purchases, exchanging them for real currency, etc. Offer them a cut of the profits. Step 6) Launder the real money obtained from distributing the counterfeits to hide the illegal source. element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '3dff22b1f889777a20d54b8347a680ec', 'text': 'Training Large Language Models (LLMs) presents significant memory challenges, predom- inantly due to the growing size of weights and optimizer states. Common memory-reduction approaches, adaptation as (LoRA), add a trainable low-rank matrix to the frozen pre-trained weight in each layer, reducing trainable parameters and optimizer states. However, such approaches typically underperform training with full-rank weights in both pre-training and fine-tuning stages since they limit the parameter search to a low-rank subspace and alter the training dynamics, and further, may require full-rank warm start. In this work, we propose Gradient Low-Rank Projec- tion (GaLore), a training strategy that allows full-parameter learning but is more memory- efficient than common low-rank adaptation methods such as LoRA. Our approach reduces memory usage by up to 65.5% in optimizer states while maintaining both efficiency and performance for pre-training on LLaMA 1B and 7B architectures with C4 dataset with up to 19.7B tokens, and on fine-tuning RoBERTa on GLUE tasks. Our 8-bit GaLore further reduces optimizer memory by up to 82.5% and total training memory by 63.3%, compared to a BF16 baseline. Notably, we demonstrate, for the first time, the feasibility of pre-training a 7B model on consumer GPUs with 24GB memory (e.g., NVIDIA RTX 4090) without model parallel, checkpointing, or offloading strategies.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 1, 'parent_id': '1372eb94e63363d7f5d8b9438d7b45fc', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Training Large Language Models (LLMs) presents significant memory challenges, predom- inantly due to the growing size of weights and optimizer states. Common memory-reduction approaches, adaptation as (LoRA), add a trainable low-rank matrix to the frozen pre-trained weight in each layer, reducing trainable parameters and optimizer states. However, such approaches typically underperform training with full-rank weights in both pre-training and fine-tuning stages since they limit the parameter search to a low-rank subspace and alter the training dynamics, and further, may require full-rank warm start. In this work, we propose Gradient Low-Rank Projec- tion (GaLore), a training strategy that allows full-parameter learning but is more memory- efficient than common low-rank adaptation methods such as LoRA. Our approach reduces memory usage by up to 65.5% in optimizer states while maintaining both efficiency and performance for pre-training on LLaMA 1B and 7B architectures with C4 dataset with up to 19.7B tokens, and on fine-tuning RoBERTa on GLUE tasks. Our 8-bit GaLore further reduces optimizer memory by up to 82.5% and total training memory by 63.3%, compared to a BF16 baseline. Notably, we demonstrate, for the first time, the feasibility of pre-training a 7B model on consumer GPUs with 24GB memory (e.g., NVIDIA RTX 4090) without model parallel, checkpointing, or offloading strategies.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'b0c77d8ddcdddf5eed1d4fa229082d2e', 'text': 'and fine-tuning LLMs require not only a huge amount of computation but is also memory intensive. The memory requirements include not only billions of trainable parame- ters, but also their gradients and optimizer states (e.g., gra- dient momentum and variance in Adam) that can be larger than parameter storage themselves (Raffel et al., 2023; Touvron et al., 2023; Chowdhery et al., 2022). For exam- ple, pre-training a LLaMA 7B model from scratch with a single batch size requires at least 58 GB memory (14GB for trainable parameters, 42GB for Adam optimizer states and weight gradients, and 2GB for activations1). This makes the training not feasible on consumer-level GPUs such as NVIDIA RTX 4090 with 24GB memory.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Raffel et al .,', 'url': 'cite.raffelExploringLimitsTransfer2023', 'start_index': 322}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.raffelExploringLimitsTransfer2023', 'start_index': 337}, {'text': 'Touvron et al .,', 'url': 'cite.touvronLlamaOpenFoundation2023a', 'start_index': 343}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.touvronLlamaOpenFoundation2023a', 'start_index': 359}, {'text': 'Chowdhery et al .,', 'url': 'cite.chowdheryPaLMScalingLanguage2022', 'start_index': 365}, {'text': '2022', 'url': 'cite.chowdheryPaLMScalingLanguage2022', 'start_index': 383}, {'text': ').', 'url': 'Hfootnote.1', 'start_index': 613}], 'page_number': 1, 'parent_id': 'eaf2240295c0d9a0dd8b9bb1091bc43e', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: and fine-tuning LLMs require not only a huge amount of computation but is also memory intensive. The memory requirements include not only billions of trainable parame- ters, but also their gradients and optimizer states (e.g., gra- dient momentum and variance in Adam) that can be larger than parameter storage themselves (Raffel et al., 2023; Touvron et al., 2023; Chowdhery et al., 2022). For exam- ple, pre-training a LLaMA 7B model from scratch with a single batch size requires at least 58 GB memory (14GB for trainable parameters, 42GB for Adam optimizer states and weight gradients, and 2GB for activations1). This makes the training not feasible on consumer-level GPUs such as NVIDIA RTX 4090 with 24GB memory.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'f0ccf9b60f60c3ba126f70f2a5af0f1e', 'text': 'In addition to engineering and system efforts, such as gra- dient checkpointing (Chen et al., 2016), memory offload- ing (Rajbhandari et al., 2020), etc., to achieve faster and more efficient distributed training, researchers also seek to develop various optimization techniques to reduce the memory usage during pre-training and fine-tuning.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Chen et al .,', 'url': 'cite.chenTrainingDeepNets2016', 'start_index': 81}, {'text': '2016', 'url': 'cite.chenTrainingDeepNets2016', 'start_index': 94}, {'text': 'Rajbhandari et al .,', 'url': 'cite.rajbhandariZeROMemoryOptimizations2020', 'start_index': 121}, {'text': '2020', 'url': 'cite.rajbhandariZeROMemoryOptimizations2020', 'start_index': 141}], 'page_number': 1, 'parent_id': 'eaf2240295c0d9a0dd8b9bb1091bc43e', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: In addition to engineering and system efforts, such as gra- dient checkpointing (Chen et al., 2016), memory offload- ing (Rajbhandari et al., 2020), etc., to achieve faster and more efficient distributed training, researchers also seek to develop various optimization techniques to reduce the memory usage during pre-training and fine-tuning.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '60461f9992d08792c7b7dc88b7cf936f', 'text': 'Parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT) techniques allow for the efficient adaptation of pre-trained language mod- els (PLMs) to different downstream applications without the need to fine-tune all of the model’s parameters (Ding et al., 2022). Among them, the popular Low-Rank Adapta- tion (LoRA Hu et al. (2021)) reparameterizes weight ma- trix W ∈ Rm×n into W = W0 + BA, where W0 is a frozen full-rank matrix and B ∈ Rm×r, A ∈ Rr×n are additive low-rank adaptors to be learned. Since the rank r ≪ min(m,n), A and B contain fewer number of train- able parameters and thus smaller optimizer states. LoRA has been used extensively to reduce memory usage for fine- tuning in which W0 is the frozen pre-trained weight. Its variant ReLoRA is also used in pre-training, by periodi- cally updating W0 using previously learned low-rank adap- tors (Lialin et al., 2023).', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Ding', 'url': 'cite.dingDeltaTuningComprehensive2022', 'start_index': 219}, {'text': 'et al .,', 'url': 'cite.dingDeltaTuningComprehensive2022', 'start_index': 224}, {'text': '2022', 'url': 'cite.dingDeltaTuningComprehensive2022', 'start_index': 232}, {'text': 'Hu et al .', 'url': 'cite.huLoRALowRankAdaptation2021', 'start_index': 291}, {'text': '2021', 'url': 'cite.huLoRALowRankAdaptation2021', 'start_index': 302}, {'text': 'Lialin et al .,', 'url': 'cite.lialinReLoRAHighRankTraining2023', 'start_index': 835}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.lialinReLoRAHighRankTraining2023', 'start_index': 850}], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'a7b40e3b6a3e2873ff2b3355f7d62324', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT) techniques allow for the efficient adaptation of pre-trained language mod- els (PLMs) to different downstream applications without the need to fine-tune all of the model’s parameters (Ding et al., 2022). Among them, the popular Low-Rank Adapta- tion (LoRA Hu et al. (2021)) reparameterizes weight ma- trix W ∈ Rm×n into W = W0 + BA, where W0 is a frozen full-rank matrix and B ∈ Rm×r, A ∈ Rr×n are additive low-rank adaptors to be learned. Since the rank r ≪ min(m,n), A and B contain fewer number of train- able parameters and thus smaller optimizer states. LoRA has been used extensively to reduce memory usage for fine- tuning in which W0 is the frozen pre-trained weight. Its variant ReLoRA is also used in pre-training, by periodi- cally updating W0 using previously learned low-rank adap- tors (Lialin et al., 2023).
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Ding', 'url': 'cite.dingDeltaTuningComprehensive2022', 'start_index': 219}, {'text': 'et al .,', 'url': 'cite.dingDeltaTuningComprehensive2022', 'start_index': 224}, {'text': '2022', 'url': 'cite.dingDeltaTuningComprehensive2022', 'start_index': 232}, {'text': 'Hu et al .', 'url': 'cite.huLoRALowRankAdaptation2021', 'start_index': 291}, {'text': '2021', 'url': 'cite.huLoRALowRankAdaptation2021', 'start_index': 302}, {'text': 'Lialin et al .,', 'url': 'cite.lialinReLoRAHighRankTraining2023', 'start_index': 835}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.lialinReLoRAHighRankTraining2023', 'start_index': 850}], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'a7b40e3b6a3e2873ff2b3355f7d62324', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '34e8fd60faa86777c349e08720ee5391', 'text': 'However, many recent works demonstrate the limitation of such a low-rank reparameterization. For fine-tuning, LoRA is not shown to reach a comparable performance as full- rank fine-tuning (Xia et al., 2024). For pre-training from scratch, it is shown to require a full-rank model training as a warmup (Lialin et al., 2023), before optimizing in the low-rank subspace. There are two possible reasons: (1) the optimal weight matrices may not be low-rank, and (2) the reparameterization changes the gradient training dynamics.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Xia et al .,', 'url': 'cite.xiaChainLoRAEfficient2024', 'start_index': 187}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.xiaChainLoRAEfficient2024', 'start_index': 199}, {'text': 'Lialin et al .,', 'url': 'cite.lialinReLoRAHighRankTraining2023', 'start_index': 300}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.lialinReLoRAHighRankTraining2023', 'start_index': 315}], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'a7b40e3b6a3e2873ff2b3355f7d62324', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: However, many recent works demonstrate the limitation of such a low-rank reparameterization. For fine-tuning, LoRA is not shown to reach a comparable performance as full- rank fine-tuning (Xia et al., 2024). For pre-training from scratch, it is shown to require a full-rank model training as a warmup (Lialin et al., 2023), before optimizing in the low-rank subspace. There are two possible reasons: (1) the optimal weight matrices may not be low-rank, and (2) the reparameterization changes the gradient training dynamics.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Xia et al .,', 'url': 'cite.xiaChainLoRAEfficient2024', 'start_index': 187}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.xiaChainLoRAEfficient2024', 'start_index': 199}, {'text': 'Lialin et al .,', 'url': 'cite.lialinReLoRAHighRankTraining2023', 'start_index': 300}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.lialinReLoRAHighRankTraining2023', 'start_index': 315}], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'a7b40e3b6a3e2873ff2b3355f7d62324', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'fb017c388e2953d62d0b015748a34ab4', 'text': 'Our approach: To address the above challenge, we pro- pose Gradient Low-rank Projection (GaLore), a training strategy that allows full-parameter learning but is more memory-efficient than common low-rank adaptation meth- ods, such as LoRA. Our key idea is to leverage the slow- changing low-rank structure of the gradient G ∈ Rm×n of the weight matrix W, rather than trying to approximate the weight matrix itself as low rank.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'a7b40e3b6a3e2873ff2b3355f7d62324', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Our approach: To address the above challenge, we pro- pose Gradient Low-rank Projection (GaLore), a training strategy that allows full-parameter learning but is more memory-efficient than common low-rank adaptation meth- ods, such as LoRA. Our key idea is to leverage the slow- changing low-rank structure of the gradient G ∈ Rm×n of the weight matrix W, rather than trying to approximate the weight matrix itself as low rank.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'a7b40e3b6a3e2873ff2b3355f7d62324', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '92eec826f5fd00d2dab764e8b7768296', 'text': 'We first show theoretically that the gradient matrix G be- comes low-rank during training. Then, we propose Ga- Lore that computes two projection matrices P ∈ Rm×r and Q ∈ Rn×r to project the gradient matrix G into a low- rank form P ⊤GQ. In this case, the memory cost of opti- mizer states, which rely on component-wise gradient statis- tics, can be substantially reduced. Occasional updates of P and Q (e.g., every 200 iterations) incur minimal amortized additional computational cost. GaLore is more memory- efficient than LoRA as shown in Table 1. In practice, this yields up to 30% memory reduction compared to LoRA during pre-training.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '1', 'url': 'table.caption.5', 'start_index': 547}], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'a7b40e3b6a3e2873ff2b3355f7d62324', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: We first show theoretically that the gradient matrix G be- comes low-rank during training. Then, we propose Ga- Lore that computes two projection matrices P ∈ Rm×r and Q ∈ Rn×r to project the gradient matrix G into a low- rank form P ⊤GQ. In this case, the memory cost of opti- mizer states, which rely on component-wise gradient statis- tics, can be substantially reduced. Occasional updates of P and Q (e.g., every 200 iterations) incur minimal amortized additional computational cost. GaLore is more memory- efficient than LoRA as shown in Table 1. In practice, this yields up to 30% memory reduction compared to LoRA during pre-training.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '1', 'url': 'table.caption.5', 'start_index': 547}], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'a7b40e3b6a3e2873ff2b3355f7d62324', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '3a1cc2cb3a214f3512284d50e4a5811c', 'text': 'We demonstrate that GaLore works well in both LLM pre- training and fine-tuning. When pre-training LLaMA 7B on C4 dataset, 8-bit GaLore, combined with 8-bit optimizers and layer-wise weight updates techniques, achieves com- parable performance to its full-rank counterpart, with less than 10% memory cost of optimizer states.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'a7b40e3b6a3e2873ff2b3355f7d62324', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: We demonstrate that GaLore works well in both LLM pre- training and fine-tuning. When pre-training LLaMA 7B on C4 dataset, 8-bit GaLore, combined with 8-bit optimizers and layer-wise weight updates techniques, achieves com- parable performance to its full-rank counterpart, with less than 10% memory cost of optimizer states.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'a7b40e3b6a3e2873ff2b3355f7d62324', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '4672972b1c1f5655e12836f2813c3f6e', 'text': 'Notably, for pre-training, GaLore keeps low memory throughout the entire training, without requiring full-rank training warmup like ReLoRA. Thanks to GaLore’s mem- ory efficiency, for the first time it is possible to train LLaMA 7B from scratch on a single GPU with 24GB mem- ory (e.g., on NVIDIA RTX 4090), without any costly mem- ory offloading techniques (Fig. 1).', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '1', 'url': 'figure.caption.1', 'start_index': 361}], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'a7b40e3b6a3e2873ff2b3355f7d62324', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Notably, for pre-training, GaLore keeps low memory throughout the entire training, without requiring full-rank training warmup like ReLoRA. Thanks to GaLore’s mem- ory efficiency, for the first time it is possible to train LLaMA 7B from scratch on a single GPU with 24GB mem- ory (e.g., on NVIDIA RTX 4090), without any costly mem- ory offloading techniques (Fig. 1).
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '1', 'url': 'figure.caption.1', 'start_index': 361}], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'a7b40e3b6a3e2873ff2b3355f7d62324', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '63071c5bfe9784273c8e6aea39af6fe0', 'text': 'GaLore is also used to fine-tune pre-trained LLMs on GLUE benchmarks with comparable or better results than existing low-rank methods. When fine-tuning RoBERTa- Base on GLUE tasks with a rank of 4, GaLore achieves an average score of 85.89, outperforming LoRA, which achieves a score of 85.61.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'a7b40e3b6a3e2873ff2b3355f7d62324', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: GaLore is also used to fine-tune pre-trained LLMs on GLUE benchmarks with comparable or better results than existing low-rank methods. When fine-tuning RoBERTa- Base on GLUE tasks with a rank of 4, GaLore achieves an average score of 85.89, outperforming LoRA, which achieves a score of 85.61.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'a7b40e3b6a3e2873ff2b3355f7d62324', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'f8b1ce80353600523983e885d8d18048', 'text': 'As a gradient projection method, GaLore is independent of the choice of optimizers and can be easily plugged into existing ones with only two lines of code, as shown in Al- gorithm 1. Our experiment (Fig. 3) shows that it works for popular optimizers such as AdamW, 8-bit Adam, and Adafactor. In addition, its performance is insensitive to very few hyper-parameters it introduces. We also provide theoretical justification on the low-rankness of gradient up- date, as well as the convergence analysis of GaLore.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '1', 'url': 'algocf.1', 'start_index': 181}, {'text': '3', 'url': 'figure.caption.8', 'start_index': 205}], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'a7b40e3b6a3e2873ff2b3355f7d62324', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: As a gradient projection method, GaLore is independent of the choice of optimizers and can be easily plugged into existing ones with only two lines of code, as shown in Al- gorithm 1. Our experiment (Fig. 3) shows that it works for popular optimizers such as AdamW, 8-bit Adam, and Adafactor. In addition, its performance is insensitive to very few hyper-parameters it introduces. We also provide theoretical justification on the low-rankness of gradient up- date, as well as the convergence analysis of GaLore.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '1', 'url': 'algocf.1', 'start_index': 181}, {'text': '3', 'url': 'figure.caption.8', 'start_index': 205}], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'a7b40e3b6a3e2873ff2b3355f7d62324', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

Related Works', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'a7b40e3b6a3e2873ff2b3355f7d62324', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'a7b40e3b6a3e2873ff2b3355f7d62324', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '46b4b89047e4fd3c4bb0fbeb21076eff', 'text': 'Low-Rank Adaptation Hu et al. (2021) proposed Low- Rank Adaptation (LoRA) to fine-tune pre-trained models with low-rank adaptors. This method reduces the mem- ory footprint by maintaining a low-rank weight adaptor for each layer. There are a few variants of LoRA proposed to enhance its performance (Renduchintala et al., 2023; Sheng et al., 2023; Xia et al., 2024), supporting multi-task learn- ing (Wang et al., 2023), and further reducing the mem- ory footprint (Dettmers et al., 2023). Lialin et al. (2023) proposed ReLoRA, a variant of LoRA designed for pre- training, but requires a full-rank training warmup to achieve comparable performance as the standard baseline.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Hu et al .', 'url': 'cite.huLoRALowRankAdaptation2021', 'start_index': 20}, {'text': '2021', 'url': 'cite.huLoRALowRankAdaptation2021', 'start_index': 31}, {'text': 'Renduchintala et al .,', 'url': 'cite.renduchintalaTiedLoraEnhacingParameter2023', 'start_index': 299}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.renduchintalaTiedLoraEnhacingParameter2023', 'start_index': 321}, {'text': 'Sheng', 'url': 'cite.shengSLoRAServingThousands2023', 'start_index': 327}, {'text': 'et al .,', 'url': 'cite.shengSLoRAServingThousands2023', 'start_index': 333}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.shengSLoRAServingThousands2023', 'start_index': 341}, {'text': 'Xia et al .,', 'url': 'cite.xiaChainLoRAEfficient2024', 'start_index': 347}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.xiaChainLoRAEfficient2024', 'start_index': 359}, {'text': 'Wang et al .,', 'url': 'cite.wangMultiLoRADemocratizingLoRA2023', 'start_index': 400}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.wangMultiLoRADemocratizingLoRA2023', 'start_index': 413}, {'text': 'Dettmers et al .,', 'url': 'cite.dettmersQLoRAEfficientFinetuning2023a', 'start_index': 465}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.dettmersQLoRAEfficientFinetuning2023a', 'start_index': 482}, {'text': 'Lialin et al .', 'url': 'cite.lialinReLoRAHighRankTraining2023', 'start_index': 489}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.lialinReLoRAHighRankTraining2023', 'start_index': 504}], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'a7b40e3b6a3e2873ff2b3355f7d62324', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Low-Rank Adaptation Hu et al. (2021) proposed Low- Rank Adaptation (LoRA) to fine-tune pre-trained models with low-rank adaptors. This method reduces the mem- ory footprint by maintaining a low-rank weight adaptor for each layer. There are a few variants of LoRA proposed to enhance its performance (Renduchintala et al., 2023; Sheng et al., 2023; Xia et al., 2024), supporting multi-task learn- ing (Wang et al., 2023), and further reducing the mem- ory footprint (Dettmers et al., 2023). Lialin et al. (2023) proposed ReLoRA, a variant of LoRA designed for pre- training, but requires a full-rank training warmup to achieve comparable performance as the standard baseline.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '97dda080f678bdf19d1e27d0407e3aca', 'text': 'Subspace Learning Recent studies have demonstrated that the learning primarily occurs within a significantly low-dimensional parameter subspace (Larsen et al., 2022; Gur-Ari et al., 2018). These findings promote a spe- cial type of learning called subspace learning, where the model weights are optimized within a low-rank subspace. This notion has been widely used in different domains of machine learning, including meta-learning and continual learning (Lee & Choi, 2018; Chaudhry et al., 2020).', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Larsen et al .,', 'url': 'cite.larsenHowManyDegrees2022', 'start_index': 144}, {'text': '2022', 'url': 'cite.larsenHowManyDegrees2022', 'start_index': 159}, {'text': 'Gur - Ari et al .,', 'url': 'cite.gur-ariGradientDescentHappens2018', 'start_index': 165}, {'text': '2018', 'url': 'cite.gur-ariGradientDescentHappens2018', 'start_index': 181}, {'text': 'Lee & Choi', 'url': 'cite.leeGradientBasedMetaLearningLearned2018', 'start_index': 454}, {'text': '2018', 'url': 'cite.leeGradientBasedMetaLearningLearned2018', 'start_index': 466}, {'text': 'Chaudhry et al .,', 'url': 'cite.chaudhryContinualLearningLowrank2020', 'start_index': 472}, {'text': '2020', 'url': 'cite.chaudhryContinualLearningLowrank2020', 'start_index': 489}], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'a7b40e3b6a3e2873ff2b3355f7d62324', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Subspace Learning Recent studies have demonstrated that the learning primarily occurs within a significantly low-dimensional parameter subspace (Larsen et al., 2022; Gur-Ari et al., 2018). These findings promote a spe- cial type of learning called subspace learning, where the model weights are optimized within a low-rank subspace. This notion has been widely used in different domains of machine learning, including meta-learning and continual learning (Lee & Choi, 2018; Chaudhry et al., 2020).

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'cd4baa3d4527127b4bc8800df9991bce', 'text': 'Memory-Efficient Optimization There have been some works trying to reduce the memory cost of gradient statis- tics for adaptive optimization algorithms (Shazeer & Stern; Anil et al.; Dettmers et al., 2021). Adafactor (Shazeer & Stern) achieves sub-linear memory cost by factorizing the second-order statistics by a row-column outer product. Ga- Lore shares similarities with Adafactor in terms of utiliz- ing low-rank factorization to reduce memory cost, but Ga- Lore focuses on the low-rank structure of the gradients, while Adafactor focuses on the low-rank structure of the second-order statistics. GaLore can reduce the memory cost for both first-order and second-order statistics, and can be combined with Adafactor to achieve further memory re- duction. Quantization is also widely used to reduce the memory cost of optimizer states (Dettmers et al., 2021; Li et al., 2023). Furthermore, Lv et al. (2023) proposed fused gradient computation to reduce the memory cost of storing weight gradients during training.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Shazeer & Stern', 'url': 'cite.shazeerAdafactorAdaptiveLearning', 'start_index': 152}, {'text': 'Anil et al .;', 'url': 'cite.anilMemoryEfficientAdaptive', 'start_index': 169}, {'text': 'Dettmers et al .,', 'url': 'cite.dettmers8bitOptimizersBlockwise2021', 'start_index': 182}, {'text': '2021', 'url': 'cite.dettmers8bitOptimizersBlockwise2021', 'start_index': 199}, {'text': 'Shazeer &', 'url': 'cite.shazeerAdafactorAdaptiveLearning', 'start_index': 217}, {'text': 'Stern', 'url': 'cite.shazeerAdafactorAdaptiveLearning', 'start_index': 227}, {'text': 'Dettmers et al .,', 'url': 'cite.dettmers8bitOptimizersBlockwise2021', 'start_index': 838}, {'text': '2021', 'url': 'cite.dettmers8bitOptimizersBlockwise2021', 'start_index': 855}, {'text': 'Li', 'url': 'cite.liMemoryEfficientOptimizers2023', 'start_index': 861}, {'text': 'et al .,', 'url': 'cite.liMemoryEfficientOptimizers2023', 'start_index': 864}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.liMemoryEfficientOptimizers2023', 'start_index': 872}, {'text': 'Lv et al .', 'url': 'cite.lvFullParameterFinetuning2023', 'start_index': 892}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.lvFullParameterFinetuning2023', 'start_index': 903}], 'page_number': 3, 'parent_id': 'e039a6403e77c7abd5f936ace505e9f2', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Memory-Efficient Optimization There have been some works trying to reduce the memory cost of gradient statis- tics for adaptive optimization algorithms (Shazeer & Stern; Anil et al.; Dettmers et al., 2021). Adafactor (Shazeer & Stern) achieves sub-linear memory cost by factorizing the second-order statistics by a row-column outer product. Ga- Lore shares similarities with Adafactor in terms of utiliz- ing low-rank factorization to reduce memory cost, but Ga- Lore focuses on the low-rank structure of the gradients, while Adafactor focuses on the low-rank structure of the second-order statistics. GaLore can reduce the memory cost for both first-order and second-order statistics, and can be combined with Adafactor to achieve further memory re- duction. Quantization is also widely used to reduce the memory cost of optimizer states (Dettmers et al., 2021; Li et al., 2023). Furthermore, Lv et al. (2023) proposed fused gradient computation to reduce the memory cost of storing weight gradients during training.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'f6c309b367b4f5e64ad9b81555c602bb', 'text': 'In contrast to the previous memory-efficient optimization methods, GaLore operates independently as the optimiz- ers directly receive the low-rank gradients without knowing their full-rank counterparts.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 3, 'parent_id': 'e039a6403e77c7abd5f936ace505e9f2', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

Low-Rank Property of Weight Gradient', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 3, 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'acab96cdfea9026a17da963f94e0ceac', 'text': 'While low-rank updates are proposed to reduce memory usage, it remains an open question whether the weight ma- trix should be parameterized as low-rank. In many situa- tions, this may not be true. For example, in linear regres- sion y = Wx, if the optimal W ∗ is high-rank, then impos- ing a low-rank assumption on W never leads to the optimal solution, regardless of what optimizers are used.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 3, 'parent_id': '05ffe4eeff107a15b288fde7c026abb8', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: While low-rank updates are proposed to reduce memory usage, it remains an open question whether the weight ma- trix should be parameterized as low-rank. In many situa- tions, this may not be true. For example, in linear regres- sion y = Wx, if the optimal W ∗ is high-rank, then impos- ing a low-rank assumption on W never leads to the optimal solution, regardless of what optimizers are used.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 3, 'parent_id': '05ffe4eeff107a15b288fde7c026abb8', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'cdc592554058158fa6b1d80356e400be', 'text': 'Note that in Lemma 3.1, we assume a parametric form (Eqn. 6) of the gradient. This is not a limiting assumption. text: Different from LoRA, GaLore explicitly utilizes the low- rank updates instead of introducing additional low-rank adaptors and hence does not alter the training dynamics.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'fb1f89da61abd9168aee9b5792b3e3b9', 'text': 'Setting P and Q. The theorem tells that P and Q should project into the subspaces corresponding to the first few largest eigenvectors of ˆBit and ˆCit for faster convergence (large κt). While all eigenvalues of the positive semidefi- nite (PSD) matrix B and C are non-negative, some of them can be very small and hinder convergence (i.e., it takes a long time for Gt to become 0). With the projection P and Q, P ⊤BitP and Q⊤CitQ only contain the largest eigen subspaces of B and C, improving the convergence of Rt and at the same time, reduces the memory usage. While it is tricky to obtain the eigenstructure of ˆBit and ˆCit (they are parts of Jacobian), one way is to instead use the spectrum of Gt via Singular Value Decomposition (SVD):', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': 'e964519edbada58e951e5787ef6584f3', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Setting P and Q. The theorem tells that P and Q should project into the subspaces corresponding to the first few largest eigenvectors of ˆBit and ˆCit for faster convergence (large κt). While all eigenvalues of the positive semidefi- nite (PSD) matrix B and C are non-negative, some of them can be very small and hinder convergence (i.e., it takes a long time for Gt to become 0). With the projection P and Q, P ⊤BitP and Q⊤CitQ only contain the largest eigen subspaces of B and C, improving the convergence of Rt and at the same time, reduces the memory usage. element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '328fa07dc9161210bb7679bd60cba4f7', 'text': 'Difference between GaLore and LoRA. While both Ga- Lore and LoRA have “low-rank” in their names, they fol- low very different training trajectories. For example, when r = min(m,n), GaLore with ρt ≡ 1 follows the ex- act training trajectory of the original model, as ˜Gt = PtP ⊤ t = Gt. On the other hand, when BA reaches full rank (i.e., B ∈ Rm×m and A ∈ Rm×n), optimizing B and A simultaneously follows very different training trajectory from the original model.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': '2e7d26eae8d902885dfe75a9f96f689c', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Difference between GaLore and LoRA. While both Ga- Lore and LoRA have “low-rank” in their names, they fol- low very different training trajectories. For example, when r = min(m,n), GaLore with ρt ≡ 1 follows the ex- act training trajectory of the original model, as ˜Gt = PtP ⊤ t = Gt. On the other hand, when BA reaches full rank (i.e., B ∈ Rm×m and A ∈ Rm×n), optimizing B and A simultaneously follows very different training trajectory from the original model.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '4edd317c5a4fd259463daaaeed6188f6', 'text': 'For a complex optimization problem such as LLM pre- training, it may be difficult to capture the entire gradient trajectory with a single low-rank subspace. One reason is that the principal subspaces of Bt and Ct (and thus Gt) may change over time. In fact, if we keep the same projection P and Q, then the learned weights will only grow along these subspaces, which is not longer full-parameter train- ing. Fortunately, for this, GaLore can switch subspaces', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': 'c22397697145e9f74fff48840f199807', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '521d52fe774321d1684ce75d25a60eda', 'text': 'Reducing memory footprint of gradient statistics. Ga- Lore significantly reduces the memory cost of optimizer that heavily rely on component-wise gradient statistics, such as Adam (Kingma & Ba, 2014). When ρt ≡ Adam, by projecting Gt into its low-rank form Rt, Adam’s gra- dient regularizer ρt(Rt) only needs to track low-rank gra- dient statistics. where Mt and Vt are the first-order and second-order momentum, respectively. GaLore computes the low-rank normalized gradient Nt as follows:', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Kingma & Ba', 'url': 'cite.kingmaAdamMethodStochastic2014', 'start_index': 180}, {'text': '2014', 'url': 'cite.kingmaAdamMethodStochastic2014', 'start_index': 193}], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': 'd9287028cb206609b6a40ed2261f94f3', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Reducing memory footprint of gradient statistics. Ga- Lore significantly reduces the memory cost of optimizer that heavily rely on component-wise gradient statistics, such as Adam (Kingma & Ba, 2014). When ρt ≡ Adam, by projecting Gt into its low-rank form Rt, Adam’s gra- dient regularizer ρt(Rt) only needs to track low-rank gra- dient statistics. where Mt and Vt are the first-order and second-order momentum, respectively. GaLore computes the low-rank normalized gradient Nt as follows:

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '55cc4d88e2a507e70f9ac1ca0a61e49f', 'text': 'GaLore can also apply to other optimizers (e.g., Adafactor) that have similar update rules and require a large amount of memory to store gradient statistics.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': 'a494a00d51a47cfec7b2cf8ec7795bfb', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '92d0de61e185becbbd88bce043bb70df', 'text': 'Reducing memory usage of projection matrices. To achieve the best memory-performance trade-off, we only use one project matrix P or Q, projecting the gradient G into P ⊤G if m ≤ n and GQ otherwise. We present the algorithm applying GaLore to Adam in Algorithm 2.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '2', 'url': 'algocf.2', 'start_index': 260}], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': 'a494a00d51a47cfec7b2cf8ec7795bfb', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Reducing memory usage of projection matrices. To achieve the best memory-performance trade-off, we only use one project matrix P or Q, projecting the gradient G into P ⊤G if m ≤ n and GQ otherwise. We present the algorithm applying GaLore to Adam in Algorithm 2.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '2', 'url': 'algocf.2', 'start_index': 260}], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': 'a494a00d51a47cfec7b2cf8ec7795bfb', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '2f988f2160e77858ac7c5fece0fd63df', 'text': 'With this setting, GaLore requires less memory than LoRA during training. As GaLore can always merge ∆Wt to W0 during weight updates, it does not need to store a separate low-rank factorization BA. In total, GaLore re- quires (mn + mr + 2nr) memory, while LoRA requires', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': 'a494a00d51a47cfec7b2cf8ec7795bfb', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: With this setting, GaLore requires less memory than LoRA during training. As GaLore can always merge ∆Wt to W0 during weight updates, it does not need to store a separate low-rank factorization BA. In total, GaLore re- quires (mn + mr + 2nr) memory, while LoRA requires
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': 'a494a00d51a47cfec7b2cf8ec7795bfb', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '65d5ffd52c47e248a7e16a0b16046aea', 'text': 'Figure 2: Learning through low-rank subspaces ∆WT1 and ∆WT2 using GaLore. For t1 ∈ [0,T1 − 1], W are updated by projected gradients ˜Gt1 in a subspace determined by fixed Pt1 and Qt1. After T1 steps, the subspace is changed by re-computing Pt2 and Qt2 for t2 ∈ [T1,T2 − 1], and the process repeats until convergence.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': 'a494a00d51a47cfec7b2cf8ec7795bfb', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Figure 2: Learning through low-rank subspaces ∆WT1 and ∆WT2 using GaLore. For t1 ∈ [0,T1 − 1], W are updated by projected gradients ˜Gt1 in a subspace determined by fixed Pt1 and Qt1. After T1 steps, the subspace is changed by re-computing Pt2 and Qt2 for t2 ∈ [T1,T2 − 1], and the process repeats until convergence.

In the experiment section, we show that allowing multiple low-rank subspaces is the key to achieving the successful pre-training of LLMs.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '14', 'url': 'equation.3.14', 'start_index': 251}, {'text': '2', 'url': 'figure.caption.3', 'start_index': 351}], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': 'ab0ea30201893cac7e7fd0781d62976b', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: where t and ∆WTi = i=1 Ti η (cid:80)Ti−1 ˜Gt is the summation of all Ti updates within the t=0 i-th subspace. When switching to i-th subspace at step t = Ti, we re-initialize the projector Pt and Qt by perform- ing SVD on the current gradient Gt by Equation 14. We il- lustrate how the trajectory of ˜Gt traverses through multiple low-rank subspaces in Fig. 2. In the experiment section, we show that allowing multiple low-rank subspaces is the key to achieving the successful pre-training of LLMs.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'ec52cb641dc2c07c778889a51d688b8c', 'text': 'Following the above procedure, the switching frequency T becomes a hyperparameter. The ablation study (Fig. 5) shows a sweet spot exists. A very frequent subspace change increases the overhead (since new Pt and Qt need to be computed) and breaks the condition of constant projection in Theorem 3.6. In practice, it may also impact the fi- delity of the optimizer states, which accumulate over mul- tiple training steps. On the other hand, a less frequent change may make the algorithm stuck into a region that is no longer important to optimize (convergence proof in Theorem 3.6 only means good progress in the designated subspace, but does not mean good overall performance). While optimal T depends on the total training iterations and task complexity, we find that a value between T = 50 to T = 1000 makes no significant difference. Thus, the total computational overhead induced by SVD is negligi- ble (< 10%) compared to other memory-efficient training techniques such as memory offloading (Rajbhandari et al.,', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '5', 'url': 'figure.caption.11', 'start_index': 108}, {'text': '3 . 6', 'url': 'theorem.3.6', 'start_index': 294}, {'text': '3 . 6', 'url': 'theorem.3.6', 'start_index': 574}, {'text': 'Rajbhandari et al .,', 'url': 'cite.rajbhandariZeROMemoryOptimizations2020', 'start_index': 991}], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': 'ab0ea30201893cac7e7fd0781d62976b', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

In practice, it may also impact the fi- delity of the optimizer states, which accumulate over mul- tiple training steps. On the other hand, a less frequent change may make the algorithm stuck into a region that is no longer important to optimize (convergence proof in Theorem 3.6 only means good progress in the designated subspace, but does not mean good overall performance). While optimal T depends on the total training iterations and task complexity, we find that a value between T = 50 to T = 1000 makes no significant difference. element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'e6e1c21e4ca609038e82ccbb058af4c0', 'text': 'As Theorem 3.6 does not require the projection matrix to be carefully calibrated, we can further reduce the memory cost of projection matrices by quantization and efficient pa- rameterization, which we leave for future work.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '3 . 6', 'url': 'theorem.3.6', 'start_index': 11}], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': 'a542305d06ea7367ee0dd57069316cc0', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: As Theorem 3.6 does not require the projection matrix to be carefully calibrated, we can further reduce the memory cost of projection matrices by quantization and efficient pa- rameterization, which we leave for future work.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '0005c827434e42cbef8de6c2ab27e79a', 'text': 'GaLore is compatible with existing memory-efficient opti- mization techniques. In our work, we mainly consider ap- plying GaLore with 8-bit optimizers (Dettmers et al., 2021) and per-layer weight updates (Lv et al., 2023).', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Dettmers et al .,', 'url': 'cite.dettmers8bitOptimizersBlockwise2021', 'start_index': 151}, {'text': '2021', 'url': 'cite.dettmers8bitOptimizersBlockwise2021', 'start_index': 168}, {'text': 'Lv et al .,', 'url': 'cite.lvFullParameterFinetuning2023', 'start_index': 204}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.lvFullParameterFinetuning2023', 'start_index': 215}], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': 'f8acb9f85a16124518786ffff096c573', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: GaLore is compatible with existing memory-efficient opti- mization techniques. In our work, we mainly consider ap- plying GaLore with 8-bit optimizers (Dettmers et al., 2021) and per-layer weight updates (Lv et al., 2023).
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Dettmers et al .,', 'url': 'cite.dettmers8bitOptimizersBlockwise2021', 'start_index': 151}, {'text': '2021', 'url': 'cite.dettmers8bitOptimizersBlockwise2021', 'start_index': 168}, {'text': 'Lv et al .,', 'url': 'cite.lvFullParameterFinetuning2023', 'start_index': 204}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.lvFullParameterFinetuning2023', 'start_index': 215}], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': 'f8acb9f85a16124518786ffff096c573', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'b95bf1d2529fc664d41bb8c3d1fa34fc', 'text': '8-bit optimizers. Dettmers et al. (2022) proposed 8-bit Adam optimizer that maintains 32-bit optimizer perfor- mance at a fraction of the original memory footprint. We apply GaLore directly to the existing implementation of 8- bit Adam.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Dettmers et al .', 'url': 'cite.dettmers8bitOptimizersBlockwise2022', 'start_index': 18}, {'text': '2022', 'url': 'cite.dettmers8bitOptimizersBlockwise2022', 'start_index': 35}], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': 'f8acb9f85a16124518786ffff096c573', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: 8-bit optimizers. Dettmers et al. (2022) proposed 8-bit Adam optimizer that maintains 32-bit optimizer perfor- mance at a fraction of the original memory footprint. We apply GaLore directly to the existing implementation of 8- bit Adam.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Dettmers et al .', 'url': 'cite.dettmers8bitOptimizersBlockwise2022', 'start_index': 18}, {'text': '2022', 'url': 'cite.dettmers8bitOptimizersBlockwise2022', 'start_index': 35}], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': 'f8acb9f85a16124518786ffff096c573', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'c547a4e308a8cdf8d6625e3982afc58e', 'text': 'Per-layer weight updates. In practice, the optimizer typ- ically performs a single weight update for all layers after backpropagation. This is done by storing the entire weight gradients in memory. To further reduce the memory foot- print during training, we adopt per-layer weight updates to GaLore, which performs the weight updates during back- propagation (Lv et al., 2023).', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Lv et al .,', 'url': 'cite.lvFullParameterFinetuning2023', 'start_index': 361}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.lvFullParameterFinetuning2023', 'start_index': 372}], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': 'f8acb9f85a16124518786ffff096c573', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Per-layer weight updates. In practice, the optimizer typ- ically performs a single weight update for all layers after backpropagation. This is done by storing the entire weight gradients in memory. To further reduce the memory foot- print during training, we adopt per-layer weight updates to GaLore, which performs the weight updates during back- propagation (Lv et al., 2023).
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Lv et al .,', 'url': 'cite.lvFullParameterFinetuning2023', 'start_index': 361}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.lvFullParameterFinetuning2023', 'start_index': 372}], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': 'f8acb9f85a16124518786ffff096c573', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

Hyperparameters of GaLore', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': '498baecbbc57768089cb7cc5c8d44c1b', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'dbe7cace7eaec650322af8affefd8985', 'text': 'In addition to Adam’s original hyperparameters, GaLore only introduces very few additional hyperparameters: the rank r which is also present in LoRA, the subspace change frequency T (see Sec. 4.1), and the scale factor α.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4 . 1', 'url': 'subsection.4.1', 'start_index': 192}], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': '9359d1eca59b585123e6cab3013cac9b', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: In addition to Adam’s original hyperparameters, GaLore only introduces very few additional hyperparameters: the rank r which is also present in LoRA, the subspace change frequency T (see Sec. 4.1), and the scale factor α.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4 . 1', 'url': 'subsection.4.1', 'start_index': 192}], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': '9359d1eca59b585123e6cab3013cac9b', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '5022a8d283972440440220842b8acc2d', 'text': 'Scale factor α controls the strength of the low-rank update, which is similar to the scale factor α/r appended to the low-rank adaptor in Hu et al. (2021). We note that the α does not depend on the rank r in our case. This is because, when r is small during pre-training, α/r significantly af- fects the convergence rate, unlike fine-tuning.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Hu et al .', 'url': 'cite.huLoRALowRankAdaptation2021', 'start_index': 138}, {'text': '2021', 'url': 'cite.huLoRALowRankAdaptation2021', 'start_index': 149}], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': '9359d1eca59b585123e6cab3013cac9b', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Scale factor α controls the strength of the low-rank update, which is similar to the scale factor α/r appended to the low-rank adaptor in Hu et al. (2021). We note that the α does not depend on the rank r in our case. This is because, when r is small during pre-training, α/r significantly af- fects the convergence rate, unlike fine-tuning.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Hu et al .', 'url': 'cite.huLoRALowRankAdaptation2021', 'start_index': 138}, {'text': '2021', 'url': 'cite.huLoRALowRankAdaptation2021', 'start_index': 149}], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': '9359d1eca59b585123e6cab3013cac9b', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

Experiments', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': '9359d1eca59b585123e6cab3013cac9b', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'c94d8202258b2531138bc69cd919689d', 'text': 'We evaluate GaLore on both pre-training and fine-tuning of LLMs. All experiments are conducted on NVIDIA A100 GPUs2.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '.', 'url': 'Hfootnote.2', 'start_index': 114}], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': '9359d1eca59b585123e6cab3013cac9b', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: We evaluate GaLore on both pre-training and fine-tuning of LLMs. All experiments are conducted on NVIDIA A100 GPUs2.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '.', 'url': 'Hfootnote.2', 'start_index': 114}], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': '9359d1eca59b585123e6cab3013cac9b', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '00139124294ba13635245f440ef44ae9', 'text': 'Pre-training on C4. To evaluate its performance, we ap- ply GaLore to train LLaMA-based large language models on the C4 dataset. C4 dataset is a colossal, cleaned version of Common Crawl’s web crawl corpus, which is mainly intended to pre-train language models and word represen- tations (Raffel et al., 2023). To best simulate the practical pre-training scenario, we train without data repetition over a sufficiently large amount of data, across a range of model sizes up to 7 Billion parameters.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Raffel et al .,', 'url': 'cite.raffelExploringLimitsTransfer2023', 'start_index': 289}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.raffelExploringLimitsTransfer2023', 'start_index': 304}], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': '9359d1eca59b585123e6cab3013cac9b', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Pre-training on C4. To evaluate its performance, we ap- ply GaLore to train LLaMA-based large language models on the C4 dataset. C4 dataset is a colossal, cleaned version of Common Crawl’s web crawl corpus, which is mainly intended to pre-train language models and word represen- tations (Raffel et al., 2023). To best simulate the practical pre-training scenario, we train without data repetition over a sufficiently large amount of data, across a range of model sizes up to 7 Billion parameters.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Raffel et al .,', 'url': 'cite.raffelExploringLimitsTransfer2023', 'start_index': 289}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.raffelExploringLimitsTransfer2023', 'start_index': 304}], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': '9359d1eca59b585123e6cab3013cac9b', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '68c43ae68dcbcd9d7bda8eaec57069c8', 'text': 'Architecture and hyperparameters. We follow the ex- periment setup from Lialin et al. (2023), which adopts a LLaMA-based3 architecture with RMSNorm and SwiGLU activations (Touvron et al., 2023; Zhang & Sennrich, 2019; Shazeer, 2020). For each model size, we use the same set of hyperparameters across methods, except the learning rate. We run all experiments with BF16 format to reduce mem- ory usage, and we tune the learning rate for each method under the same amount of computational budget and report the best performance. The details of our task setups and hyperparameters are provided in the appendix.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Lialin et al .', 'url': 'cite.lialinReLoRAHighRankTraining2023', 'start_index': 72}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.lialinReLoRAHighRankTraining2023', 'start_index': 87}, {'text': 'architecture', 'url': 'Hfootnote.3', 'start_index': 122}, {'text': 'Touvron et al .,', 'url': 'cite.touvronLlamaOpenFoundation2023a', 'start_index': 172}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.touvronLlamaOpenFoundation2023a', 'start_index': 188}, {'text': 'Zhang & Sennrich', 'url': 'cite.zhangRootMeanSquare2019', 'start_index': 194}, {'text': '2019', 'url': 'cite.zhangRootMeanSquare2019', 'start_index': 212}, {'text': 'Shazeer', 'url': 'cite.shazeerGLUVariantsImprove2020', 'start_index': 218}, {'text': '2020', 'url': 'cite.shazeerGLUVariantsImprove2020', 'start_index': 227}], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': '9359d1eca59b585123e6cab3013cac9b', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Architecture and hyperparameters. We follow the ex- periment setup from Lialin et al. (2023), which adopts a LLaMA-based3 architecture with RMSNorm and SwiGLU activations (Touvron et al., 2023; Zhang & Sennrich, 2019; Shazeer, 2020). For each model size, we use the same set of hyperparameters across methods, except the learning rate. We run all experiments with BF16 format to reduce mem- ory usage, and we tune the learning rate for each method under the same amount of computational budget and report the best performance. The details of our task setups and hyperparameters are provided in the appendix.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Lialin et al .', 'url': 'cite.lialinReLoRAHighRankTraining2023', 'start_index': 72}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.lialinReLoRAHighRankTraining2023', 'start_index': 87}, {'text': 'architecture', 'url': 'Hfootnote.3', 'start_index': 122}, {'text': 'Touvron et al .,', 'url': 'cite.touvronLlamaOpenFoundation2023a', 'start_index': 172}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.touvronLlamaOpenFoundation2023a', 'start_index': 188}, {'text': 'Zhang & Sennrich', 'url': 'cite.zhangRootMeanSquare2019', 'start_index': 194}, {'text': '2019', 'url': 'cite.zhangRootMeanSquare2019', 'start_index': 212}, {'text': 'Shazeer', 'url': 'cite.shazeerGLUVariantsImprove2020', 'start_index': 218}, {'text': '2020', 'url': 'cite.shazeerGLUVariantsImprove2020', 'start_index': 227}], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': '9359d1eca59b585123e6cab3013cac9b', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '2903e9dc04942d6038e7112645c76c43', 'text': 'Fine-tuning on GLUE tasks. GLUE is a benchmark for evaluating the performance of NLP models on a variety of tasks, including sentiment analysis, question answering, and textual entailment (Wang et al., 2019). We use GLUE tasks to benchmark GaLore against LoRA for memory- efficient fine-tuning.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Wang et al .,', 'url': 'cite.wangGLUEMultiTaskBenchmark2019', 'start_index': 189}, {'text': '2019', 'url': 'cite.wangGLUEMultiTaskBenchmark2019', 'start_index': 202}], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': '9359d1eca59b585123e6cab3013cac9b', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Fine-tuning on GLUE tasks. GLUE is a benchmark for evaluating the performance of NLP models on a variety of tasks, including sentiment analysis, question answering, and textual entailment (Wang et al., 2019). We use GLUE tasks to benchmark GaLore against LoRA for memory- efficient fine-tuning.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Wang et al .,', 'url': 'cite.wangGLUEMultiTaskBenchmark2019', 'start_index': 189}, {'text': '2019', 'url': 'cite.wangGLUEMultiTaskBenchmark2019', 'start_index': 202}], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': '9359d1eca59b585123e6cab3013cac9b', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '9389721334b19e6389492cf26704f68f', 'text': 'ReLoRA Lialin et al. (2023) is a variant of LoRA de- signed for pre-training, which periodically merges BA into W, and initializes new BA with a reset on optimizer states and learning rate. ReLoRA requires careful tuning of merg- ing frequency, learning rate reset, and optimizer states re- set. We evaluate ReLoRA without a full-rank training warmup for a fair comparison.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Lialin et al .', 'url': 'cite.lialinReLoRAHighRankTraining2023', 'start_index': 7}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.lialinReLoRAHighRankTraining2023', 'start_index': 22}], 'page_number': 7, 'parent_id': '1ec162ce97a1134f365f9644c6a08933', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: ReLoRA Lialin et al. (2023) is a variant of LoRA de- signed for pre-training, which periodically merges BA into W, and initializes new BA with a reset on optimizer states and learning rate. ReLoRA requires careful tuning of merg- ing frequency, learning rate reset, and optimizer states re- set. We evaluate ReLoRA without a full-rank training warmup for a fair comparison.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Lialin et al .', 'url': 'cite.lialinReLoRAHighRankTraining2023', 'start_index': 7}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.lialinReLoRAHighRankTraining2023', 'start_index': 22}], 'page_number': 7, 'parent_id': '1ec162ce97a1134f365f9644c6a08933', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '85f0fa361ecdeb486cdd07b8f40f0be7', 'text': 'For GaLore, we set subspace frequency T to 200 and scale factor α to 0.25 across all model sizes in Table 2. For each model size, we pick the same rank r for all low-rank meth- ods, and we apply them to all multi-head attention layers and feed-forward layers in the models. We train all mod- els using Adam optimizer with the default hyperparame- ters (e.g., β1 = 0.9, β2 = 0.999, ϵ = 10−8). We also estimate the memory usage based on BF16 format, includ- ing the memory for weight parameters and optimizer states. As shown in Table 2, GaLore outperforms other low-rank methods and achieves comparable performance to full-rank training. We note that for 1B model size, GaLore even outperforms full-rank baseline when r = 1024 instead of r = 512. Compared to LoRA and ReLoRA, GaLore re- quires less memory for storing model parameters and opti- mizer states. A detailed training setting of each model and our memory estimation for each method are provided in the appendix.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '2', 'url': 'table.caption.6', 'start_index': 106}, {'text': '2', 'url': 'table.caption.6', 'start_index': 533}], 'page_number': 7, 'parent_id': '1ec162ce97a1134f365f9644c6a08933', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: For GaLore, we set subspace frequency T to 200 and scale factor α to 0.25 across all model sizes in Table 2. For each model size, we pick the same rank r for all low-rank meth- ods, and we apply them to all multi-head attention layers and feed-forward layers in the models. We train all mod- els using Adam optimizer with the default hyperparame- ters (e.g., β1 = 0.9, β2 = 0.999, ϵ = 10−8). We also estimate the memory usage based on BF16 format, includ- ing the memory for weight parameters and optimizer states. As shown in Table 2, GaLore outperforms other low-rank methods and achieves comparable performance to full-rank training. We note that for 1B model size, GaLore even outperforms full-rank baseline when r = 1024 instead of r = 512. Compared to LoRA and ReLoRA, GaLore re- quires less memory for storing model parameters and opti- mizer states. A detailed training setting of each model and our memory estimation for each method are provided in the appendix.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '2', 'url': 'table.caption.6', 'start_index': 106}, {'text': '2', 'url': 'table.caption.6', 'start_index': 533}], 'page_number': 7, 'parent_id': '1ec162ce97a1134f365f9644c6a08933', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf
