element_id: {'type': 'Title', 'element_id': '81fbcec5d26aa6fe087ba2226bcaf5dd', 'text': '5.2. GaLore with Memory-Efficient Optimizers', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 7, 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 7, 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '05495fe916f46b5c52e3b16151ee1075', 'text': 'We demonstrate that GaLore can be applied to various learning algorithms, especially memory-efficient optimiz- ers, to further reduce the memory footprint. We apply Ga- Lore to AdamW, 8-bit Adam, and Adafactor optimizers (Loshchilov & Hutter, 2019; Dettmers et al., 2022; Shazeer & Stern). We consider Adafactor with first-order statistics to avoid performance degradation.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Loshchilov & Hutter', 'url': 'cite.loshchilovDecoupledWeightDecay2019', 'start_index': 221}, {'text': '2019', 'url': 'cite.loshchilovDecoupledWeightDecay2019', 'start_index': 242}, {'text': 'Dettmers et al .,', 'url': 'cite.dettmers8bitOptimizersBlockwise2022', 'start_index': 248}, {'text': '2022', 'url': 'cite.dettmers8bitOptimizersBlockwise2022', 'start_index': 265}, {'text': 'Shazeer', 'url': 'cite.shazeerAdafactorAdaptiveLearning', 'start_index': 271}, {'text': '& Stern', 'url': 'cite.shazeerAdafactorAdaptiveLearning', 'start_index': 279}], 'page_number': 7, 'parent_id': '81fbcec5d26aa6fe087ba2226bcaf5dd', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: We demonstrate that GaLore can be applied to various learning algorithms, especially memory-efficient optimiz- ers, to further reduce the memory footprint. We apply Ga- Lore to AdamW, 8-bit Adam, and Adafactor optimizers (Loshchilov & Hutter, 2019; Dettmers et al., 2022; Shazeer & Stern). We consider Adafactor with first-order statistics to avoid performance degradation.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Loshchilov & Hutter', 'url': 'cite.loshchilovDecoupledWeightDecay2019', 'start_index': 221}, {'text': '2019', 'url': 'cite.loshchilovDecoupledWeightDecay2019', 'start_index': 242}, {'text': 'Dettmers et al .,', 'url': 'cite.dettmers8bitOptimizersBlockwise2022', 'start_index': 248}, {'text': '2022', 'url': 'cite.dettmers8bitOptimizersBlockwise2022', 'start_index': 265}, {'text': 'Shazeer', 'url': 'cite.shazeerAdafactorAdaptiveLearning', 'start_index': 271}, {'text': '& Stern', 'url': 'cite.shazeerAdafactorAdaptiveLearning', 'start_index': 279}], 'page_number': 7, 'parent_id': '81fbcec5d26aa6fe087ba2226bcaf5dd', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'c0a408bf97cce5436ca70a2b4758280a', 'text': 'We evaluate them on LLaMA 1B architecture with 10K training steps, and we tune the learning rate for each set- ting and report the best performance. As shown in Fig. 3, applying GaLore does not significantly affect their conver- gence. By using GaLore with a rank of 512, the memory footprint is reduced by up to 62.5%, on top of the mem- ory savings from using 8-bit Adam or Adafactor optimizer. Since 8-bit Adam requires less memory than others, we de- note 8-bit GaLore as GaLore with 8-bit Adam, and use it as the default method for the following experiments on 7B model pre-training and memory measurement.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '3', 'url': 'figure.caption.8', 'start_index': 166}], 'page_number': 7, 'parent_id': '81fbcec5d26aa6fe087ba2226bcaf5dd', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: We evaluate them on LLaMA 1B architecture with 10K training steps, and we tune the learning rate for each set- ting and report the best performance. As shown in Fig. 3, applying GaLore does not significantly affect their conver- gence. By using GaLore with a rank of 512, the memory footprint is reduced by up to 62.5%, on top of the mem- ory savings from using 8-bit Adam or Adafactor optimizer. Since 8-bit Adam requires less memory than others, we de- note 8-bit GaLore as GaLore with 8-bit Adam, and use it as the default method for the following experiments on 7B model pre-training and memory measurement.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '3', 'url': 'figure.caption.8', 'start_index': 166}], 'page_number': 7, 'parent_id': '81fbcec5d26aa6fe087ba2226bcaf5dd', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

Scaling up to LLaMA 7B Architecture', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 7, 'parent_id': '81fbcec5d26aa6fe087ba2226bcaf5dd', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 7, 'parent_id': '81fbcec5d26aa6fe087ba2226bcaf5dd', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'eafaa58fd938be14d9e5280f6e8447e6', 'text': 'Scaling ability to 7B models is a key factor for demonstrat- ing if GaLore is effective for practical LLM pre-training scenarios. We evaluate GaLore on an LLaMA 7B archi- tecture with an embedding size of 4096 and total layers of 32. We train the model for 150K steps with 19.7B tokens, using 8-node training in parallel with a total of 64 A100 GPUs. Due to computational constraints, we only compare 8-bit GaLore (r = 1024) with 8-bit Adam with a single trial without tuning the hyperparameters. As shown in Ta- ble 3, after 150K steps, 8-bit GaLore achieves a perplexity of 14.65, which is comparable to 8-bit Adam with a per- plexity of 14.61.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '3', 'url': 'table.caption.7', 'start_index': 517}], 'page_number': 7, 'parent_id': '81fbcec5d26aa6fe087ba2226bcaf5dd', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Scaling ability to 7B models is a key factor for demonstrat- ing if GaLore is effective for practical LLM pre-training scenarios. We evaluate GaLore on an LLaMA 7B archi- tecture with an embedding size of 4096 and total layers of 32. We train the model for 150K steps with 19.7B tokens, using 8-node training in parallel with a total of 64 A100 GPUs. Due to computational constraints, we only compare 8-bit GaLore (r = 1024) with 8-bit Adam with a single trial without tuning the hyperparameters. As shown in Ta- ble 3, after 150K steps, 8-bit GaLore achieves a perplexity of 14.65, which is comparable to 8-bit Adam with a per- plexity of 14.61.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'f1570456038ec3ba1d5b2970b13ebaef', 'text': 'fine-tune pre-trained RoBERTa models on GLUE tasks us- ing GaLore and compare its performance with a full fine- tuning baseline and LoRA. We use hyperparameters from Hu et al. (2021) for LoRA and tune the learning rate and scale factor for GaLore. As shown in Table 4, GaLore achieves better performance than LoRA on most tasks with less memory footprint. This demonstrates that GaLore can serve as a full-stack memory-efficient training strategy for both LLM pre-training and fine-tuning.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Hu et al .', 'url': 'cite.huLoRALowRankAdaptation2021', 'start_index': 164}, {'text': '2021', 'url': 'cite.huLoRALowRankAdaptation2021', 'start_index': 175}, {'text': '4', 'url': 'table.caption.10', 'start_index': 264}], 'page_number': 8, 'parent_id': '43c15297be61bc1904bcc6cd83dc6671', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: fine-tune pre-trained RoBERTa models on GLUE tasks us- ing GaLore and compare its performance with a full fine- tuning baseline and LoRA. We use hyperparameters from Hu et al. (2021) for LoRA and tune the learning rate and scale factor for GaLore. As shown in Table 4, GaLore achieves better performance than LoRA on most tasks with less memory footprint. This demonstrates that GaLore can serve as a full-stack memory-efficient training strategy for both LLM pre-training and fine-tuning.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '6f7d9acb7390acb795f8e1f0000a49b2', 'text': 'While Table 2 gives the theoretical benefit of GaLore com- pared to other methods in terms of memory usage, we also measure the actual memory footprint of training LLaMA models by various methods, with a token batch size of 256. The training is conducted on a single device setup with- out activation checkpointing, memory offloading, and opti- mizer states partitioning (Rajbhandari et al., 2020).', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '2', 'url': 'table.caption.6', 'start_index': 12}, {'text': 'Rajbhandari et al .,', 'url': 'cite.rajbhandariZeROMemoryOptimizations2020', 'start_index': 370}, {'text': '2020', 'url': 'cite.rajbhandariZeROMemoryOptimizations2020', 'start_index': 390}], 'page_number': 8, 'parent_id': '7c2f148c8042cec4b51f4a51a4e73757', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: While Table 2 gives the theoretical benefit of GaLore com- pared to other methods in terms of memory usage, we also measure the actual memory footprint of training LLaMA models by various methods, with a token batch size of 256. The training is conducted on a single device setup with- out activation checkpointing, memory offloading, and opti- mizer states partitioning (Rajbhandari et al., 2020).

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '823facbcff944cd8d8c1bef61c67596c', 'text': 'and only requires 22.0G memory to pre-train LLaMA 7B with a small per-GPU token batch size (up to 500 tokens). This memory footprint is within 24GB VRAM capacity of a single GPU such as NVIDIA RTX 4090. In addition, when activation checkpointing is enabled, per-GPU token batch size can be increased up to 4096. While the batch size is small per GPU, it can be scaled up with data parallelism, which requires much lower bandwidth for inter-GPU com- munication, compared to model parallelism. Therefore, it is possible that GaLore can be used for elastic training (Lin et al.) 7B models on consumer GPUs such as RTX 4090s.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Lin', 'url': 'cite.linDynamicMinibatchSGD2019', 'start_index': 564}], 'page_number': 8, 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: and only requires 22.0G memory to pre-train LLaMA 7B with a small per-GPU token batch size (up to 500 tokens). This memory footprint is within 24GB VRAM capacity of a single GPU such as NVIDIA RTX 4090. In addition, when activation checkpointing is enabled, per-GPU token batch size can be increased up to 4096. While the batch size is small per GPU, it can be scaled up with data parallelism, which requires much lower bandwidth for inter-GPU com- munication, compared to model parallelism. Therefore, it is possible that GaLore can be used for elastic training (Lin et al.) 7B models on consumer GPUs such as RTX 4090s.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Lin', 'url': 'cite.linDynamicMinibatchSGD2019', 'start_index': 564}], 'page_number': 8, 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '173cedb29e81d63de2da3287f91a595b', 'text': 'Specifically, we present the memory breakdown in Fig. 1. It shows that 8-bit GaLore reduces 37.92G (63.3%) and 24.5G (52.3%) total memory compared to BF16 Adam baseline and 8-bit Adam, respectively. Compared to 8- bit Adam, 8-bit GaLore mainly reduces the memory in two parts: (1) low-rank gradient projection reduces 9.6G (65.5%) memory of storing optimizer states, and (2) using per-layer weight updates reduces 13.5G memory of storing weight gradients.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '1', 'url': 'figure.caption.1', 'start_index': 53}], 'page_number': 8, 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Specifically, we present the memory breakdown in Fig. 1. It shows that 8-bit GaLore reduces 37.92G (63.3%) and 24.5G (52.3%) total memory compared to BF16 Adam baseline and 8-bit Adam, respectively. Compared to 8- bit Adam, 8-bit GaLore mainly reduces the memory in two parts: (1) low-rank gradient projection reduces 9.6G (65.5%) memory of storing optimizer states, and (2) using per-layer weight updates reduces 13.5G memory of storing weight gradients.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '1', 'url': 'figure.caption.1', 'start_index': 53}], 'page_number': 8, 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'be13671953cc9be6b4bbb5800292efda', 'text': 'Throughput overhead of GaLore. We also measure the throughput of the pre-training LLaMA 1B model with 8-bit GaLore and other methods, where the results can be found in the appendix. Particularly, the current implementation of 8-bit GaLore achieves 1019.63 tokens/second, which induces 17% overhead compared to 8-bit Adam imple- mentation. Disabling per-layer weight updates for GaLore achieves 1109.38 tokens/second, improving the throughput by 8.8%. We note that our results do not require offloading strategies or checkpointing, which can significantly impact training throughput. We leave optimizing the efficiency of GaLore implementation for future work.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 8, 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Throughput overhead of GaLore. We also measure the throughput of the pre-training LLaMA 1B model with 8-bit GaLore and other methods, where the results can be found in the appendix. Particularly, the current implementation of 8-bit GaLore achieves 1019.63 tokens/second, which induces 17% overhead compared to 8-bit Adam imple- mentation. Disabling per-layer weight updates for GaLore achieves 1109.38 tokens/second, improving the throughput by 8.8%. We note that our results do not require offloading strategies or checkpointing, which can significantly impact training throughput. We leave optimizing the efficiency of GaLore implementation for future work.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 8, 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '67161a1463e505e3e8825057a5c69712', 'text': 'The reason has been discussed in Sec. 4.1 and is more prevalent for small r, since in such case, the subspace switching should happen at the right time to avoid wasting optimization steps in the wrong subspace, while for large r the gradient updates cover more subspaces, providing more cushion.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4 . 1', 'url': 'subsection.4.1', 'start_index': 38}], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': '561a83439db9f00a49181847e453b5bc', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: The reason has been discussed in Sec. 4.1 and is more prevalent for small r, since in such case, the subspace switching should happen at the right time to avoid wasting optimization steps in the wrong subspace, while for large r the gradient updates cover more subspaces, providing more cushion.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4 . 1', 'url': 'subsection.4.1', 'start_index': 38}], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': '561a83439db9f00a49181847e453b5bc', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'Title', 'element_id': 'edb63e6ab403e30e672b8f33b62c09d4', 'text': 'convergence?', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': 'b84d3970b434ea5a56d5d3a96091dd7e', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': 'b84d3970b434ea5a56d5d3a96091dd7e', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '4a88220d3bcd928fdec4e6201e037b2f', 'text': 'Within a certain range of rank values, decreasing the rank only slightly affects the convergence rate, causing a slow- down that is close to linear. As shown in Fig. 5(right), train- ing with a rank of 128 using 80K steps achieves a lower loss than training with a rank of 512 using 20K steps. This shows that GaLore can be used to trade-off between mem- ory and computational cost. In a memory-constrained sce- nario, reducing the rank allows us to stay within the mem- ory budget while training for more steps to preserve the performance.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '5', 'url': 'figure.caption.11', 'start_index': 166}], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': 'edb63e6ab403e30e672b8f33b62c09d4', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Within a certain range of rank values, decreasing the rank only slightly affects the convergence rate, causing a slow- down that is close to linear. As shown in Fig. 5(right), train- ing with a rank of 128 using 80K steps achieves a lower loss than training with a rank of 512 using 20K steps. This shows that GaLore can be used to trade-off between mem- ory and computational cost. In a memory-constrained sce- nario, reducing the rank allows us to stay within the mem- ory budget while training for more steps to preserve the performance.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '5', 'url': 'figure.caption.11', 'start_index': 166}], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': 'edb63e6ab403e30e672b8f33b62c09d4', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

Conclusion', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': 'edb63e6ab403e30e672b8f33b62c09d4', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': 'edb63e6ab403e30e672b8f33b62c09d4', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '25e4bbdf37f8d71208d603f9350c320c', 'text': 'We propose GaLore, a memory-efficient pre-training and fine-tuning strategy for large language models. GaLore sig- nificantly reduces memory usage by up to 65.5% in opti- mizer states while maintaining both efficiency and perfor- mance for large-scale LLM pre-training and fine-tuning.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': 'edb63e6ab403e30e672b8f33b62c09d4', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: We propose GaLore, a memory-efficient pre-training and fine-tuning strategy for large language models. GaLore sig- nificantly reduces memory usage by up to 65.5% in opti- mizer states while maintaining both efficiency and perfor- mance for large-scale LLM pre-training and fine-tuning.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': 'edb63e6ab403e30e672b8f33b62c09d4', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'Footer', 'element_id': '67095cd375174ab91b9b1c031ad5dc70', 'text': '9', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 9, 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 9, 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '7ea1be8eac9e770e57d6e93692389ca7', 'text': 'We identify several open problems for GaLore, which in- clude (1) applying GaLore on training of other types of models such as vision transformers and diffusion mod- els, (2) further improving memory efficiency by employ- ing low-memory projection matrices, through quantization or special parameterization, and (3) exploring the possi- bility of elastic data distributed training on low-bandwidth consumer-grade hardware.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 9, 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: We identify several open problems for GaLore, which in- clude (1) applying GaLore on training of other types of models such as vision transformers and diffusion mod- els, (2) further improving memory efficiency by employ- ing low-memory projection matrices, through quantization or special parameterization, and (3) exploring the possi- bility of elastic data distributed training on low-bandwidth consumer-grade hardware.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 9, 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '2df5a4d2e2e0b7dc1f9dfc355169e830', 'text': 'We hope that our work will inspire future research on memory-efficient LLM training strategies from the per- spective of low-rank gradient projection. We believe that GaLore will be a valuable tool for the community to train large language models with consumer-grade hardware and limited resources.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 9, 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: We hope that our work will inspire future research on memory-efficient LLM training strategies from the per- spective of low-rank gradient projection. We believe that GaLore will be a valuable tool for the community to train large language models with consumer-grade hardware and limited resources.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '7efa066f1e863828db25606d8562c6a6', 'text': 'This paper aims to improve the memory efficiency of train- ing large language models (LLMs) in order to reduce the environmental impact of LLM pre-training and fine-tuning. By enabling the training of larger models on hardware with lower memory, our approach helps to minimize energy consumption and carbon footprint associated with training LLMs.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 9, 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: This paper aims to improve the memory efficiency of train- ing large language models (LLMs) in order to reduce the environmental impact of LLM pre-training and fine-tuning. By enabling the training of larger models on hardware with lower memory, our approach helps to minimize energy consumption and carbon footprint associated with training LLMs.

element_id: {'type': 'Title', 'element_id': '482e3250905074a81900733d4d7d78ca', 'text': 'A.2. Reversibility', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 13, 'parent_id': '3e29b343df26f6e1283c6ace1594303a', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 13, 'parent_id': '3e29b343df26f6e1283c6ace1594303a', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '387c500cca2063d834de47767d7db96a', 'text': 'Definition A.2 (Reversiblity (Tian et al., 2020)). A network N that maps input x to output y = N(x) is reversible, if there exists K(x;W) so that y = K(x;W)x, and the backpropagated gradient gx satisfies gx = K⊤(x;W)gy, where gy is the backpropagated gradient at the output y. Here K(x;W) depends on the input x and weight W in the network N.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Tian et al .,', 'url': 'cite.tian2020understanding', 'start_index': 29}, {'text': '2020', 'url': 'cite.tian2020understanding', 'start_index': 42}], 'page_number': 13, 'parent_id': '482e3250905074a81900733d4d7d78ca', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Definition A.2 (Reversiblity (Tian et al., 2020)). A network N that maps input x to output y = N(x) is reversible, if there exists K(x;W) so that y = K(x;W)x, and the backpropagated gradient gx satisfies gx = K⊤(x;W)gy, where gy is the backpropagated gradient at the output y. Here K(x;W) depends on the input x and weight W in the network N.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Tian et al .,', 'url': 'cite.tian2020understanding', 'start_index': 29}, {'text': '2020', 'url': 'cite.tian2020understanding', 'start_index': 42}], 'page_number': 13, 'parent_id': '482e3250905074a81900733d4d7d78ca', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '8ccc6f888e237d11de5de966f039301f', 'text': 'Note that many layers are reversible, including linear layer (without bias), reversible activations (e.g., ReLU, leaky ReLU, polynomials, etc). Furthermore, they can be combined to construct more complicated architectures: Property 1. If N1 and N2 are reversible networks, then (Parallel) y = α1N1(x) + α2N2(x) is reversible for constants α1 and α2, and (Composition) y = N2(N1(x)) is reversible.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 13, 'parent_id': '482e3250905074a81900733d4d7d78ca', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Note that many layers are reversible, including linear layer (without bias), reversible activations (e.g., ReLU, leaky ReLU, polynomials, etc). Furthermore, they can be combined to construct more complicated architectures: Property 1. If N1 and N2 are reversible networks, then (Parallel) y = α1N1(x) + α2N2(x) is reversible for constants α1 and α2, and (Composition) y = N2(N1(x)) is reversible.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 13, 'parent_id': '482e3250905074a81900733d4d7d78ca', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
filename: GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '9b61c115d7e1d8c6f705b3ead09b9a6a', 'text': 'From this property, it is clear that ResNet architecture x + N(x) is reversible, if N contains bias-free linear layers and reversible activations, which is often the case in practice. For a detailed analysis, please check Appendix A in (Tian et al., 2020). For architectures like self-attention, one possibility is to leverage JoMA (Tian et al., 2024) to analyze, and we leave for future work.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Tian et al .,', 'url': 'cite.tian2020understanding', 'start_index': 237}, {'text': '2020', 'url': 'cite.tian2020understanding', 'start_index': 250}, {'text': 'Tian et al .,', 'url': 'cite.tian2023joma', 'start_index': 333}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.tian2023joma', 'start_index': 346}], 'page_number': 13, 'parent_id': '482e3250905074a81900733d4d7d78ca', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: From this property, it is clear that ResNet architecture x + N(x) is reversible, if N contains bias-free linear layers and reversible activations, which is often the case in practice. For a detailed analysis, please check Appendix A in (Tian et al., 2020). For architectures like self-attention, one possibility is to leverage JoMA (Tian et al., 2024) to analyze, and we leave for future work.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '2b62bd6a8d2c9b05dd8c39a1fcb1ba9c', 'text': 'We introduce details of the LLaMA architecture and hyperparameters used for pre-training. Table 5 shows the most hyperparameters of LLaMA models across model sizes. We use a max sequence length of 256 for all models, with a batch size of 131K tokens. For all experiments, we adopt learning rate warmup for the first 10% of the training steps, and use cosine annealing for the learning rate schedule, decaying to 10% of the initial learning rate.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '5', 'url': 'table.caption.13', 'start_index': 96}], 'page_number': 15, 'parent_id': 'e373a3b032c129b74f09089101c5b225', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: We introduce details of the LLaMA architecture and hyperparameters used for pre-training. Table 5 shows the most hyperparameters of LLaMA models across model sizes. We use a max sequence length of 256 for all models, with a batch size of 131K tokens. For all experiments, we adopt learning rate warmup for the first 10% of the training steps, and use cosine annealing for the learning rate schedule, decaying to 10% of the initial learning rate.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'b2ab8b143413f76a84ce7fe722fcdad1', 'text': 'For all methods on each size of models (from 60M to 1B), we tune their favorite learning rate from a set of {0.01,0.005,0.001,0.0005,0.0001}, and the best learning rate is chosen based on the validation perplexity. We find GaLore is insensitive to hyperparameters and tends to be stable with the same learning rate across different model sizes. For all models, GaLore use the same hyperparameters, including the learning rate of 0.01, scale factor α of 0.25, and the subspace change frequency of T of 200. We note that since α can be viewed as a fractional learning rate, most of the modules (e.g., multi-head attention and feed-forward layers) in LLaMA models have the actual learning rate of 0.0025. This is, still, a relatively large stable learning rate compared to the full-rank baseline, which usually uses a learning rate ≤ 0.001 to avoid spikes in the training loss.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 15, 'parent_id': '374c4a2d4c4d48a94762094fb69d5e17', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: For all methods on each size of models (from 60M to 1B), we tune their favorite learning rate from a set of {0.01,0.005,0.001,0.0005,0.0001}, and the best learning rate is chosen based on the validation perplexity. We find GaLore is insensitive to hyperparameters and tends to be stable with the same learning rate across different model sizes. For all models, GaLore use the same hyperparameters, including the learning rate of 0.01, scale factor α of 0.25, and the subspace change frequency of T of 200. We note that since α can be viewed as a fractional learning rate, most of the modules (e.g., multi-head attention and feed-forward layers) in LLaMA models have the actual learning rate of 0.0025. This is, still, a relatively large stable learning rate compared to the full-rank baseline, which usually uses a learning rate ≤ 0.001 to avoid spikes in the training loss.

Memory Estimates', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': '828a2a27253ba25d5ce4f4540bc03bd4', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '81bc7a58dbdd11d76acff85b69590537', 'text': 'As the GPU memory usage for a specific component is hard to measure directly, we estimate the memory usage of the weight parameters and optimizer states for each method on different model sizes. The estimation is based on the number of original parameters and the number of low-rank parameters, trained by BF16 format. For example, for a 60M model, LoRA (r = 128) requires 42.7M parameters on low-rank adaptors and 60M parameters on the original weights, resulting in a memory cost of 0.20G for weight parameters and 0.17G for optimizer states. Table 6 shows the memory estimates for weight parameters and optimizer states for different methods on different model sizes, as a compliment to the total memory reported in the main text.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '6', 'url': 'table.caption.14', 'start_index': 550}], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': 'fb217b66070a54507c0ff08fccb14a58', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: As the GPU memory usage for a specific component is hard to measure directly, we estimate the memory usage of the weight parameters and optimizer states for each method on different model sizes. The estimation is based on the number of original parameters and the number of low-rank parameters, trained by BF16 format. For example, for a 60M model, LoRA (r = 128) requires 42.7M parameters on low-rank adaptors and 60M parameters on the original weights, resulting in a memory cost of 0.20G for weight parameters and 0.17G for optimizer states. Table 6 shows the memory estimates for weight parameters and optimizer states for different methods on different model sizes, as a compliment to the total memory reported in the main text.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '881803a03000ed9c493e6e7b9b4b315f', 'text': 'We fine-tune the pre-trained RoBERTa-Base model on the GLUE benchmark using the model provided by the Hugging Face1. We trained the model for 30 epochs with a batch size of 16 for all tasks except for CoLA, which uses a batch size of 32. We tune the learning rate and scale factor for GaLore. Table 7 shows the hyperparameters used for fine-tuning RoBERTa-Base for GaLore.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '.', 'url': 'Hfootnote.4', 'start_index': 114}, {'text': '7', 'url': 'table.caption.15', 'start_index': 298}], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': '7f2b5917f452a7803377a913f8fd2609', 'filename': 'GaLore- Memory-Efficient LLM Training by Gradient Low-Rank Projection.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: We fine-tune the pre-trained RoBERTa-Base model on the GLUE benchmark using the model provided by the Hugging Face1. We trained the model for 30 epochs with a batch size of 16 for all tasks except for CoLA, which uses a batch size of 32. We tune the learning rate and scale factor for GaLore. Table 7 shows the hyperparameters used for fine-tuning RoBERTa-Base for GaLore.

{'type': 'Title', 'element_id': '8a4c414a68a1f6593d456820d9fd3e65', 'text': 'Abstract', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 1, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '58ecb972471b6fe14b298fc9b22524d5', 'text': 'We introduce the first model-stealing attack that information from extracts precise, nontrivial black-box production language models like Ope- nAI’s ChatGPT or Google’s PaLM-2. Specifi- cally, our attack recovers the embedding projec- tion layer (up to symmetries) of a transformer model, given typical API access. For under $20 USD, our attack extracts the entire projection ma- trix of OpenAI’s ada and babbage language models. We thereby confirm, for the first time, that these black-box models have a hidden di- mension of 1024 and 2048, respectively. We also recover the exact hidden dimension size of the gpt-3.5-turbo model, and estimate it would cost under $2,000 in queries to recover the entire projection matrix. We conclude with potential defenses and mitigations, and discuss the impli- cations of possible future work that could extend our attack.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 1, 'parent_id': '8a4c414a68a1f6593d456820d9fd3e65', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: We introduce the first model-stealing attack that information from extracts precise, nontrivial black-box production language models like Ope- nAI’s ChatGPT or Google’s PaLM-2. Specifi- cally, our attack recovers the embedding projec- tion layer (up to symmetries) of a transformer model, given typical API access. For under $20 USD, our attack extracts the entire projection ma- trix of OpenAI’s ada and babbage language models. We thereby confirm, for the first time, that these black-box models have a hidden di- mension of 1024 and 2048, respectively. We also recover the exact hidden dimension size of the gpt-3.5-turbo model, and estimate it would cost under $2,000 in queries to recover the entire projection matrix. We conclude with potential defenses and mitigations, and discuss the impli- cations of possible future work that could extend our attack.

element_id: {'type': 'ListItem', 'element_id': 'c198e4646d63d1cd323d985639100291', 'text': '1. Introduction', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 1, 'parent_id': '8a4c414a68a1f6593d456820d9fd3e65', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'fb8ae463efd58da466694a53535aea2f', 'text': 'Little is publicly known about the inner workings of today’s most popular large language models, such as GPT-4, Claude 2, or Gemini. The GPT-4 technical report states it “contains no [...] details about the architecture (including model size), hardware, training compute, dataset construction, training method, or similar” (OpenAI et al., 2023). Similarly, the PaLM-2 paper states that “details of [the] model size and architecture are withheld from external publication” (Anil et al., 2023). This secrecy is often ascribed to “the competi- tive landscape” (because these models are expensive to train) and the “safety implications of large-scale models” (OpenAI et al., 2023) (because it is easier to attack models when more information is available). Nevertheless, while these models’ weights and internal details are not publicly accessible, the models themselves are exposed via APIs.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'OpenAI et al .,', 'url': 'cite.openai2023gpt4', 'start_index': 324}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.openai2023gpt4', 'start_index': 339}, {'text': 'Anil', 'url': 'cite.anil2023palm', 'start_index': 473}, {'text': 'et al .,', 'url': 'cite.anil2023palm', 'start_index': 478}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.anil2023palm', 'start_index': 486}, {'text': 'OpenAI', 'url': 'cite.openai2023gpt4', 'start_index': 656}, {'text': 'et al .,', 'url': 'cite.openai2023gpt4', 'start_index': 663}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.openai2023gpt4', 'start_index': 671}], 'page_number': 1, 'parent_id': '8a4c414a68a1f6593d456820d9fd3e65', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Little is publicly known about the inner workings of today’s most popular large language models, such as GPT-4, Claude 2, or Gemini. The GPT-4 technical report states it “contains no [...] details about the architecture (including model size), hardware, training compute, dataset construction, training method, or similar” (OpenAI et al., 2023). Similarly, the PaLM-2 paper states that “details of [the] model size and architecture are withheld from external publication” (Anil et al., 2023). This secrecy is often ascribed to “the competi- tive landscape” (because these models are expensive to train) and the “safety implications of large-scale models” (OpenAI et al., 2023) (because it is easier to attack models when more information is available). Nevertheless, while these models’ weights and internal details are not publicly accessible, the models themselves are exposed via APIs.

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'bfe4e072c6ce3addf80ae5d00190a6df', 'text': 'In this paper we ask: how much information can an adver- sary learn about a production language model by making queries to its API? This is the question studied by the field of model stealing (Tramèr et al., 2016): the ability of an ad- versary to extract model weights by making queries its API.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Tramèr et al .,', 'url': 'cite.tramer2016stealing', 'start_index': 192}, {'text': '2016', 'url': 'cite.tramer2016stealing', 'start_index': 207}], 'page_number': 1, 'parent_id': 'cb1af8d796f5281fbe800f01d93941af', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: In this paper we ask: how much information can an adver- sary learn about a production language model by making queries to its API? This is the question studied by the field of model stealing (Tramèr et al., 2016): the ability of an ad- versary to extract model weights by making queries its API.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'd7dbf54fc78e3df7fc2fbadc3a7dca36', 'text': 'Contributions. We introduce an attack that can be applied to black-box language models, and allows us to recover the complete embedding projection layer of a transformer language model. Our attack departs from prior approaches that reconstruct a model in a bottom-up fashion, starting from the input layer. Instead, our attack operates top-down and directly extracts the model’s last layer. Specifically, we exploit the fact that the final layer of a language model projects from the hidden dimension to a (higher dimen- sional) logit vector. This final layer is thus low-rank, and by making targeted queries to a model’s API, we can extract its embedding dimension or its final weight matrix.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 1, 'parent_id': 'cb1af8d796f5281fbe800f01d93941af', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Contributions. We introduce an attack that can be applied to black-box language models, and allows us to recover the complete embedding projection layer of a transformer language model. Our attack departs from prior approaches that reconstruct a model in a bottom-up fashion, starting from the input layer. Instead, our attack operates top-down and directly extracts the model’s last layer. Specifically, we exploit the fact that the final layer of a language model projects from the hidden dimension to a (higher dimen- sional) logit vector. This final layer is thus low-rank, and by making targeted queries to a model’s API, we can extract its embedding dimension or its final weight matrix.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'f25da2be3a8d4890a1ba8e23220430a2', 'text': 'Stealing this layer is useful for several reasons. First, it reveals the width of the transformer model, which is often correlated with its total parameter count. Second, it slightly reduces the degree to which the model is a complete “black- box”, which so might be useful for future attacks. Third, while our attack recovers only a (relatively small) part of the entire model, the fact that it is at all possible to steal any parameters of a production model is surprising, and raises concerns that extensions of this attack might be able to recover more information. Finally, recovering the model’s last layer (and thus hidden dimension) may reveal more global information about the model, such as relative size differences between different models.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 1, 'parent_id': 'cb1af8d796f5281fbe800f01d93941af', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Stealing this layer is useful for several reasons. First, it reveals the width of the transformer model, which is often correlated with its total parameter count. Second, it slightly reduces the degree to which the model is a complete “black- box”, which so might be useful for future attacks. Third, while our attack recovers only a (relatively small) part of the entire model, the fact that it is at all possible to steal any parameters of a production model is surprising, and raises concerns that extensions of this attack might be able to recover more information. Finally, recovering the model’s last layer (and thus hidden dimension) may reveal more global information about the model, such as relative size differences between different models.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'c4828d17f4126b1f3e98fe6563c820f0', 'text': 'Our attack is effective and efficient, and is applicable to production models whose APIs expose full logprobs, or a “logit bias”. This included Google’s PaLM-2 and OpenAI’s GPT-4 (Anil et al., 2023; OpenAI et al., 2023); after respon- sible disclosure, both APIs have implemented defenses to prevent our attack or make it more expensive. We extract the embedding layer of several OpenAI models with a mean squared error of 10−4 (up to unavoidable symmetries). We apply a limited form of our attack to gpt-3.5 at a cost of un- der $200 USD and, instead of recovering the full embedding layer, recover just the size of the embedding dimension.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Anil et al .,', 'url': 'cite.anil2023palm', 'start_index': 179}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.anil2023palm', 'start_index': 192}, {'text': 'OpenAI et al .,', 'url': 'cite.openai2023gpt4', 'start_index': 198}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.openai2023gpt4', 'start_index': 213}], 'page_number': 1, 'parent_id': 'cb1af8d796f5281fbe800f01d93941af', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Our attack is effective and efficient, and is applicable to production models whose APIs expose full logprobs, or a “logit bias”. This included Google’s PaLM-2 and OpenAI’s GPT-4 (Anil et al., 2023; OpenAI et al., 2023); after respon- sible disclosure, both APIs have implemented defenses to prevent our attack or make it more expensive. We extract the embedding layer of several OpenAI models with a mean squared error of 10−4 (up to unavoidable symmetries). We apply a limited form of our attack to gpt-3.5 at a cost of un- der $200 USD and, instead of recovering the full embedding layer, recover just the size of the embedding dimension.

{'type': 'Header', 'element_id': 'f85af46b034e4be6ae98daf650f3a991', 'text': 'Stealing Part of a Production Language Model', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 2, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Stealing Part of a Production Language Model

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'fea4c39da9efa12efcadbda574eaaaf1', 'text': 'Responsible disclosure. We shared our attack with all ser- vices we are aware of that are vulnerable to this attack. We also shared our attack with several other popular services, even if they were not vulnerable to our specific attack, be- cause variants of our attack may be possible in other settings. We received approval from OpenAI prior to extracting the parameters of the last layers of their models, worked with OpenAI to confirm our approach’s efficacy, and then deleted all data associated with the attack. In response to our attack, OpenAI and Google have both modified their APIs to intro- duce mitigiations and defenses (like those that we suggest in Section 8) to make it more difficult for adversaries to perform this attack.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '8', 'url': 'section.8', 'start_index': 669}], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'f85af46b034e4be6ae98daf650f3a991', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Responsible disclosure. We shared our attack with all ser- vices we are aware of that are vulnerable to this attack. We also shared our attack with several other popular services, even if they were not vulnerable to our specific attack, be- cause variants of our attack may be possible in other settings. We received approval from OpenAI prior to extracting the parameters of the last layers of their models, worked with OpenAI to confirm our approach’s efficacy, and then deleted all data associated with the attack. In response to our attack, OpenAI and Google have both modified their APIs to intro- duce mitigiations and defenses (like those that we suggest in Section 8) to make it more difficult for adversaries to perform this attack.

element_id: {'type': 'ListItem', 'element_id': '16bbd28b3327b96738fdfc6365466fea', 'text': '2. Related Work', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'f85af46b034e4be6ae98daf650f3a991', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '4d9ed3ef06359eacd353d73f8aeca100', 'text': 'Model stealing attacks (Tramèr et al., 2016) aim to recover the functionality of a black-box model, and optimize for one of two objectives (Jagielski et al., 2020):', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Tramèr et al .,', 'url': 'cite.tramer2016stealing', 'start_index': 24}, {'text': '2016', 'url': 'cite.tramer2016stealing', 'start_index': 39}, {'text': 'Jagielski et al .,', 'url': 'cite.jagielski2020high', 'start_index': 140}, {'text': '2020', 'url': 'cite.jagielski2020high', 'start_index': 158}], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'f85af46b034e4be6ae98daf650f3a991', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Model stealing attacks (Tramèr et al., 2016) aim to recover the functionality of a black-box model, and optimize for one of two objectives (Jagielski et al., 2020):

element_id: {'type': 'ListItem', 'element_id': '5a9fe65dc3f8ba8178ef45e95ed3ef18', 'text': '1. Accuracy: the stolen model ˆf should match the perfor- mance of the target model f on some particular data domain. For example, if the target is an image clas- sifier, we might want the stolen model to match the target’s overall accuracy on ImageNet.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'f85af46b034e4be6ae98daf650f3a991', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: 1. Accuracy: the stolen model ˆf should match the perfor- mance of the target model f on some particular data domain. For example, if the target is an image clas- sifier, we might want the stolen model to match the target’s overall accuracy on ImageNet.

element_id: {'type': 'ListItem', 'element_id': '27aad6aa1ad28103773d364acea5debb', 'text': '2. Fidelity: the stolen model ˆf should be functionally equivalent to the target model f on all inputs. That is, for any valid input p, we want ˆf(p) ≈ f(p).', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'f85af46b034e4be6ae98daf650f3a991', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: 2. Fidelity: the stolen model ˆf should be functionally equivalent to the target model f on all inputs. That is, for any valid input p, we want ˆf(p) ≈ f(p).

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'd5fe1cd82179a09948f5883f5e21584e', 'text': 'In this paper, we focus on high-fidelity attacks. Most prior high-fidelity attacks exploit specific properties of deep neu- ral networks with ReLU activations. Milli et al. (2019) first showed that if an attacker can compute gradients of a target two-layer ReLU model, then they can steal a nearly bit- for-bit equivalent model. Jagielski et al. (2020) observed that if the attacker only has query access to model outputs, they can approximate gradients with finite differences. Sub- sequent work extended these attacks to efficiently extract deeper ReLU models (Carlini et al., 2020; Rolnick & Kord- ing, 2020; Shamir et al., 2023). Unfortunately, none of these approaches scale to production language models, because they (1) accept tokens as inputs (and so performing finite differences is intractable); (2) use activations other than Re- LUs; (3) contain architectural components such as attention, layer normalization, residual connections, etc. that current attacks cannot handle; (4) are orders-of-magnitude larger than prior extracted models; and (5) expose only limited- precision outputs.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Milli et al .', 'url': 'cite.milli2019model', 'start_index': 157}, {'text': '2019', 'url': 'cite.milli2019model', 'start_index': 171}, {'text': 'Jagielski et al .', 'url': 'cite.jagielski2020high', 'start_index': 325}, {'text': '2020', 'url': 'cite.jagielski2020high', 'start_index': 343}, {'text': 'Carlini et al .,', 'url': 'cite.carlini2020cryptanalytic', 'start_index': 557}, {'text': '2020', 'url': 'cite.carlini2020cryptanalytic', 'start_index': 573}, {'text': 'Rolnick & Kord -', 'url': 'cite.rolnick2020reverse', 'start_index': 579}, {'text': 'ing', 'url': 'cite.rolnick2020reverse', 'start_index': 595}, {'text': '2020', 'url': 'cite.rolnick2020reverse', 'start_index': 600}, {'text': 'Shamir et al .,', 'url': 'cite.shamir2023polynomial', 'start_index': 606}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.shamir2023polynomial', 'start_index': 621}], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'f85af46b034e4be6ae98daf650f3a991', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: In this paper, we focus on high-fidelity attacks. Most prior high-fidelity attacks exploit specific properties of deep neu- ral networks with ReLU activations. Milli et al. (2019) first showed that if an attacker can compute gradients of a target two-layer ReLU model, then they can steal a nearly bit- for-bit equivalent model. Jagielski et al. (2020) observed that if the attacker only has query access to model outputs, they can approximate gradients with finite differences. Sub- sequent work extended these attacks to efficiently extract deeper ReLU models (Carlini et al., 2020; Rolnick & Kord- ing, 2020; Shamir et al., 2023). Unfortunately, none of these approaches scale to production language models, because they (1) accept tokens as inputs (and so performing finite differences is intractable); (2) use activations other than Re- LUs; (3) contain architectural components such as attention, layer normalization, residual connections, etc. that current attacks cannot handle; (4) are orders-of-magnitude larger than prior extracted models; and (5) expose only limited- precision outputs.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Milli et al .', 'url': 'cite.milli2019model', 'start_index': 157}, {'text': '2019', 'url': 'cite.milli2019model', 'start_index': 171}, {'text': 'Jagielski et al .', 'url': 'cite.jagielski2020high', 'start_index': 325}, {'text': '2020', 'url': 'cite.jagielski2020high', 'start_index': 343}, {'text': 'Carlini et al .,', 'url': 'cite.carlini2020cryptanalytic', 'start_index': 557}, {'text': '2020', 'url': 'cite.carlini2020cryptanalytic', 'start_index': 573}, {'text': 'Rolnick & Kord -', 'url': 'cite.rolnick2020reverse', 'start_index': 579}, {'text': 'ing', 'url': 'cite.rolnick2020reverse', 'start_index': 595}, {'text': '2020', 'url': 'cite.rolnick2020reverse', 'start_index': 600}, {'text': 'Shamir et al .,', 'url': 'cite.shamir2023polynomial', 'start_index': 606}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.shamir2023polynomial', 'start_index': 621}], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'f85af46b034e4be6ae98daf650f3a991', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '5eb86bcb580a003280dbc0e524f6f219', 'text': 'Other attacks aim to recover more limited information. Wei et al. (2020) show that an adversary co-located on the same server as the LLM can recover the sizes of all hidden layers. Others have attempted to recover model sizes by correlating performance on published benchmarks with model sizes in academic papers (Gao, 2021).', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Wei', 'url': 'cite.wei2020leaky', 'start_index': 55}, {'text': 'et al .', 'url': 'cite.wei2020leaky', 'start_index': 59}, {'text': '2020', 'url': 'cite.wei2020leaky', 'start_index': 67}, {'text': 'Gao', 'url': 'cite.gao2021sizes', 'start_index': 314}, {'text': '2021', 'url': 'cite.gao2021sizes', 'start_index': 319}], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'f85af46b034e4be6ae98daf650f3a991', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Other attacks aim to recover more limited information. Wei et al. (2020) show that an adversary co-located on the same server as the LLM can recover the sizes of all hidden layers. Others have attempted to recover model sizes by correlating performance on published benchmarks with model sizes in academic papers (Gao, 2021).

We study parameterized models fθ : X N → P (X) that produce a probability distri- bution over the next output token, given an input sequence of N tokens. The model has the following structure:

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '9bd741496166535401c9a79ebf217b72', 'text': 'Threat model. Throughout the paper, we assume that the adversary does not have any additional knowledge about the model parameters. We assume access to a model fθ, hosted by a service provider and made available to users through a query interface (API) O. We assume that O is a perfect oracle: given an input sequence p, it produces y = O (p) without leaking any other information about fθ than what can be inferred from (p,y). For example, the adversary cannot infer anything about fθ via timing side-channels or other details of the implementation of the query interface.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'ac3cb7e896756b25b25ca4ffa3d3e501', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Threat model. Throughout the paper, we assume that the adversary does not have any additional knowledge about the model parameters. We assume access to a model fθ, hosted by a service provider and made available to users through a query interface (API) O. We assume that O is a perfect oracle: given an input sequence p, it produces y = O (p) without leaking any other information about fθ than what can be inferred from (p,y). For example, the adversary cannot infer anything about fθ via timing side-channels or other details of the implementation of the query interface.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'fe2a72ae9c0cf40950ee6d62832b0381', 'text': 'Different open-source and proprietary LLMs offer APIs with varying capabilities, which impact the ability to per- form model extraction attacks and the choice of attack algo- rithm. A summary of the different APIs we study, and our motivation for doing so, is presented in Table 1. The logits API is a strawman threat model where the API provides log- its for all tokens in the response to a given prompt. We begin with this toy setting, as the attack techniques we develop here can be reused in subsequent sections, where we will first reconstruct the logits from more limited information (e.g., log-probabilities for only the top few tokens) and then run the attack.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '1', 'url': 'table.caption.1', 'start_index': 279}], 'page_number': 2, 'parent_id': 'ac3cb7e896756b25b25ca4ffa3d3e501', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Different open-source and proprietary LLMs offer APIs with varying capabilities, which impact the ability to per- form model extraction attacks and the choice of attack algo- rithm. A summary of the different APIs we study, and our motivation for doing so, is presented in Table 1. The logits API is a strawman threat model where the API provides log- its for all tokens in the response to a given prompt. We begin with this toy setting, as the attack techniques we develop here can be reused in subsequent sections, where we will first reconstruct the logits from more limited information (e.g., log-probabilities for only the top few tokens) and then run the attack.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '4ca09b491304a8a31adc36b550017bfa', 'text': 'We develop new attack techniques that allow us to perform high-fidelity extraction of (a small part of) a transformer. Section 4.1 demonstrates how we can identify the hidden dimension h using the logits API and Section 4.2 presents an algorithm that can recover the matrix W.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4 . 1', 'url': 'subsection.4.1', 'start_index': 126}, {'text': '4 . 2', 'url': 'subsection.4.2', 'start_index': 219}], 'page_number': 3, 'parent_id': '7bf61a156317a97c0f9423f639d0709e', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: We develop new attack techniques that allow us to perform high-fidelity extraction of (a small part of) a transformer. Section 4.1 demonstrates how we can identify the hidden dimension h using the logits API and Section 4.2 presents an algorithm that can recover the matrix W.

Warm-up: Recovering Hidden Dimensionality', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 3, 'parent_id': '394ca7386315abcb98b85e54690b2dd3', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '084022fa4ce0758ea7b639a4ffcd6e1b', 'text': 'We begin with a simple attack that allows an adversary to re- cover the size of the hidden dimension of a language model by making queries to the oracle O (Algorithm 1). The tech- niques we use to perform this attack will be the foundation for attacks that we further develop to perform complete extraction of the final embedding projection matrix.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '1', 'url': 'algorithm.1', 'start_index': 166}], 'page_number': 3, 'parent_id': 'c4eea1230383f9c7c0042f13b63f1315', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: We begin with a simple attack that allows an adversary to re- cover the size of the hidden dimension of a language model by making queries to the oracle O (Algorithm 1). The tech- niques we use to perform this attack will be the foundation for attacks that we further develop to perform complete extraction of the final embedding projection matrix.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '2e1a3a3619cd6fa7d1133478239c8549', 'text': 'Algorithm 1 Hidden-Dimension Extraction Attack Require: Oracle LLM O 1: Initialize n to an appropriate value greater than h 2: Initialize an empty matrix Q = 0n×l 3: for i = 1 to n do 4: 5: 6: end for 7: λ1 ≥ λ2 ≥ ··· ≥ λn ← SingularValues(Q) 8: count ← argmaxi log∥λi∥ − log∥λi+1∥ 9: return count', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 3, 'parent_id': 'c4eea1230383f9c7c0042f13b63f1315', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Algorithm 1 Hidden-Dimension Extraction Attack Require: Oracle LLM O 1: Initialize n to an appropriate value greater than h 2: Initialize an empty matrix Q = 0n×l 3: for i = 1 to n do 4: 5: 6: end for 7: λ1 ≥ λ2 ≥ ··· ≥ λn ← SingularValues(Q) 8: count ← argmaxi log∥λi∥ − log∥λi+1∥ 9: return count

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'de71034371390dcf6ed9c6831a669f56', 'text': '▷ Choose a random prompt', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 3, 'parent_id': '2289af30895157cb6ab4fe60104c8393', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'f17ef45d4a34dd40be16bfd7d415a2da', 'text': 'Intuition. Suppose we query a language model on a large number of different random prefixes. Even though each output logit vector is an l-dimensional vector, they all actu- ally lie in a h-dimensional subspace because the embedding projection layer up-projects from h-dimensions. Therefore, by querying the model “enough” (more than h times) we will eventually observe new queries are linearly dependent of past queries. We can then compute the dimensionality of this subspace (e.g., with SVD) and report this as the hidden dimensionality of the model.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 3, 'parent_id': '2289af30895157cb6ab4fe60104c8393', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Intuition. Suppose we query a language model on a large number of different random prefixes. Even though each output logit vector is an l-dimensional vector, they all actu- ally lie in a h-dimensional subspace because the embedding projection layer up-projects from h-dimensions. Therefore, by querying the model “enough” (more than h times) we will eventually observe new queries are linearly dependent of past queries. We can then compute the dimensionality of this subspace (e.g., with SVD) and report this as the hidden dimensionality of the model.

text: Formalization. The attack is based on the following straightforward mathematical result: Lemma 4.1. Let Q(p1,...pn) ∈ Rl×n denote the matrix with columns O (p1),...,O (pn) of query responses from the logit-vector API. Then

We can precisely identify the size by obtaining slightly over 2048 full logit vectors.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 3, 'parent_id': 'b868ff3a5d89e71310b7a82bf510b650', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Figure 1. SVD can recover the hidden dimensionality of a model when the final output layer dimension is greater than the hidden dimension. Here we extract the hidden dimension (2048) of the Pythia 1.4B model. We can precisely identify the size by obtaining slightly over 2048 full logit vectors.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'ba9e1e1ead4cc13743a5c65ac63a315e', 'text': 'Proof. We have Q = W · H, where H is a h × n ma- trix whose columns are gθ(pi) (i = 1,...,n). Thus, h ≥ rank(Q). Further, if H has rank h (with the second assumption), then h = rank(Q).', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 3, 'parent_id': 'b868ff3a5d89e71310b7a82bf510b650', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Proof. We have Q = W · H, where H is a h × n ma- trix whose columns are gθ(pi) (i = 1,...,n). Thus, h ≥ rank(Q). Further, if H has rank h (with the second assumption), then h = rank(Q).

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'f3a82b1435f9a9a7b26a45d4458f741c', 'text': 'Assumptions. In Lemma 4.1, we assume that both the matrix with columns gθ (pi) and the matrix W have rank h. These matrices have either h rows or h columns, so both have rank at most h. Moreover, it is very unlikely that they have rank < h: this would require the distribution of gθ (p) to be fully supported on a subspace of dimension < h across all pi we query, or all h ≪ l columns of W to lie in the same (h − 1) dimensional subspace of Rl (the output space of logits). In practice we find this assumption holds for all larger models (Table 2) and when different normalization layers are used (Appendix B.1).', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4 . 1', 'url': 'theorem.4.1', 'start_index': 22}, {'text': '2', 'url': 'table.caption.4', 'start_index': 544}, {'text': 'B . 1', 'url': 'subsection.B.1', 'start_index': 606}], 'page_number': 3, 'parent_id': 'b868ff3a5d89e71310b7a82bf510b650', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Assumptions. In Lemma 4.1, we assume that both the matrix with columns gθ (pi) and the matrix W have rank h. These matrices have either h rows or h columns, so both have rank at most h. Moreover, it is very unlikely that they have rank < h: this would require the distribution of gθ (p) to be fully supported on a subspace of dimension < h across all pi we query, or all h ≪ l columns of W to lie in the same (h − 1) dimensional subspace of Rl (the output space of logits). In practice we find this assumption holds for all larger models (Table 2) and when different normalization layers are used (Appendix B.1).

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '3784df4ba461a1704420c140f3ec330b', 'text': 'Practical considerations. Since the matrix Q is not com- puted over the reals, but over floating-point numbers (possi- bly with precision as low as 16-bits or 8-bits for production neural networks), we cannot naively take the rank to be the number of linearly independent rows. Instead, we use a practical numerical rank of Q, where we order the singular values λ1 ≥ λ2 ≥ ··· ≥ λn, and identify the largest multi- plicative gap λi between consecutive singular values. A λi+1 large multiplicative gap arises when we switch from large “actual” singular values to small singular values that arise from numerical imprecision. Figure 2 shows these gaps. Algorithm 1 describes this attack.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '2', 'url': 'figure.caption.3', 'start_index': 628}, {'text': '1', 'url': 'algorithm.1', 'start_index': 658}], 'page_number': 3, 'parent_id': 'b868ff3a5d89e71310b7a82bf510b650', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Practical considerations. Since the matrix Q is not com- puted over the reals, but over floating-point numbers (possi- bly with precision as low as 16-bits or 8-bits for production neural networks), we cannot naively take the rank to be the number of linearly independent rows. Instead, we use a practical numerical rank of Q, where we order the singular values λ1 ≥ λ2 ≥ ··· ≥ λn, and identify the largest multi- plicative gap λi between consecutive singular values. A λi+1 large multiplicative gap arises when we switch from large “actual” singular values to small singular values that arise from numerical imprecision. Figure 2 shows these gaps. Algorithm 1 describes this attack.

On Pythia-1.4B, a 2048 dimensional model, the spike occurs at 2047 singular values.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': 'b4e5fb484ce6bebbfc3a38c9552bdce8', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Figure 2. Our extraction attack recovers the hidden dimension size by looking for a sharp drop in singular values, visualized as a spike in the difference between consecutive singular values. On Pythia-1.4B, a 2048 dimensional model, the spike occurs at 2047 singular values.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'f088d307ebbc23fabb29cc04df4a73d6', 'text': 'is impossible to identify the dimensionality of the hidden space. This is because n < h, and so the n × l dimensional matrix Q has full rank and n nontrivial singular values. But once we make more than 2048 queries to the model, and thus n > h, the number of numerically significant singular values does not increase further; it is capped at exactly 2048.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': 'b4e5fb484ce6bebbfc3a38c9552bdce8', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: is impossible to identify the dimensionality of the hidden space. This is because n < h, and so the n × l dimensional matrix Q has full rank and n nontrivial singular values. But once we make more than 2048 queries to the model, and thus n > h, the number of numerically significant singular values does not increase further; it is capped at exactly 2048.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '1436cc8b6b10a69c1229b8c0530b6c08', 'text': 'In Figure 2 we plot the difference (in log-space) between subsequent singular values. As we can see, the largest difference occurs at (almost exactly) the 2048th singular value—the true hidden dimensionality of this model.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '2', 'url': 'figure.caption.3', 'start_index': 10}], 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': 'b4e5fb484ce6bebbfc3a38c9552bdce8', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: In Figure 2 we plot the difference (in log-space) between subsequent singular values. As we can see, the largest difference occurs at (almost exactly) the 2048th singular value—the true hidden dimensionality of this model.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '38e65f2f066f4c6ed7ece12fc8bff0eb', 'text': 'We now analyze the efficacy of this attack across a wider range of models: GPT-2 (Radford et al., 2019) Small and XL, Pythia (Biderman et al., 2023) 1.4B and 6.9B, and LLaMA (Touvron et al., 2023) 7B and 65B. The results are in Table 2: our attack recovers the embedding size nearly perfectly, with an error of 0 or 1 in five out of six cases.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Radford et al .,', 'url': 'cite.radford2019gpt2', 'start_index': 81}, {'text': '2019', 'url': 'cite.radford2019gpt2', 'start_index': 97}, {'text': 'Biderman et al .,', 'url': 'cite.biderman2023pythia', 'start_index': 125}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.biderman2023pythia', 'start_index': 142}, {'text': 'Touvron et al .,', 'url': 'cite.touvron2023llama', 'start_index': 174}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.touvron2023llama', 'start_index': 190}, {'text': '2', 'url': 'table.caption.4', 'start_index': 233}], 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': 'b4e5fb484ce6bebbfc3a38c9552bdce8', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: We now analyze the efficacy of this attack across a wider range of models: GPT-2 (Radford et al., 2019) Small and XL, Pythia (Biderman et al., 2023) 1.4B and 6.9B, and LLaMA (Touvron et al., 2023) 7B and 65B. The results are in Table 2: our attack recovers the embedding size nearly perfectly, with an error of 0 or 1 in five out of six cases.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Radford et al .,', 'url': 'cite.radford2019gpt2', 'start_index': 81}, {'text': '2019', 'url': 'cite.radford2019gpt2', 'start_index': 97}, {'text': 'Biderman et al .,', 'url': 'cite.biderman2023pythia', 'start_index': 125}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.biderman2023pythia', 'start_index': 142}, {'text': 'Touvron et al .,', 'url': 'cite.touvron2023llama', 'start_index': 174}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.touvron2023llama', 'start_index': 190}, {'text': '2', 'url': 'table.caption.4', 'start_index': 233}], 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': 'b4e5fb484ce6bebbfc3a38c9552bdce8', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '0c08da21ec1febd6abe6f4644385f60f', 'text': 'Our near perfect extraction has one exception: GPT-2 Small. On this 768 dimensional model our attack reports a hidden dimension of 757. In Appendix A we show that this “failure” is caused by GPT-2 actually having an effective hidden dimensionality of 757 despite having 768 dimensions.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'A', 'url': 'appendix.A', 'start_index': 148}], 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': 'b4e5fb484ce6bebbfc3a38c9552bdce8', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Our near perfect extraction has one exception: GPT-2 Small. On this 768 dimensional model our attack reports a hidden dimension of 757. In Appendix A we show that this “failure” is caused by GPT-2 actually having an effective hidden dimensionality of 757 despite having 768 dimensions.

But it turns out that the matrix U actually directly represents (a rotation of) the final layer!
