element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '7b0171861fdb7e4a4cc97c28d4d7f199', 'text': 'Lemma 4.2. In the logit-API threat model, under the as- sumptions of Lemma 4.1: (i) The method above recovers ˜W = W · G for some G ∈ Rh×h; (ii) With the addi- tional assumption that gθ(p) is a transformer with residual connections, it is impossible to extract W exactly.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4 . 1', 'url': 'theorem.4.1', 'start_index': 75}], 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': 'b538034e432bee2025d014b952897f38', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Lemma 4.2. In the logit-API threat model, under the as- sumptions of Lemma 4.1: (i) The method above recovers ˜W = W · G for some G ∈ Rh×h; (ii) With the addi- tional assumption that gθ(p) is a transformer with residual connections, it is impossible to extract W exactly.

element_id: {'type': 'Title', 'element_id': '890a5c03e154dab1f8d76e3c6b67776f', 'text': 'Proof. See Appendix C.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'C', 'url': 'appendix.C', 'start_index': 20}], 'page_number': 4, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '5e4b5306db3c59ff6054f16abe419743', 'text': 'Experiments. For the six models considered previously, we evaluate the attack success rate by comparing the root mean square (RMS) between our extracted matrix ˜W = U · Σ and the actual weight matrix, after allowing for a h × h affine transformation. Concretely, we solve the least squares system ˜W · G ≈ W for G, which reduces to h linear least squares problems, each with l equations and h unknowns. Then, we report the RMS of W and ˜W · G.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': '890a5c03e154dab1f8d76e3c6b67776f', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Experiments. For the six models considered previously, we evaluate the attack success rate by comparing the root mean square (RMS) between our extracted matrix ˜W = U · Σ and the actual weight matrix, after allowing for a h × h affine transformation. Concretely, we solve the least squares system ˜W · G ≈ W for G, which reduces to h linear least squares problems, each with l equations and h unknowns. Then, we report the RMS of W and ˜W · G.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'd28c048991b1c98c33f6676e789c4852', 'text': 'The results are in Table 2. As a point of reference, the RMS between a randomly initialized model and the actual weights is 2 · 10−2, over 100–500× higher than the error of our reconstruction.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '2', 'url': 'table.caption.4', 'start_index': 25}], 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': '890a5c03e154dab1f8d76e3c6b67776f', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: The results are in Table 2. As a point of reference, the RMS between a randomly initialized model and the actual weights is 2 · 10−2, over 100–500× higher than the error of our reconstruction.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'dee030af9015810bec2f50364baf15e8', 'text': 'In Appendices C and G, we show that reconstruction is pos- sible up an orthogonal transformation (approximately h2/2 missing parameters, as opposed to h2 for reconstruction up to an affine transformation), and that this is tight under some formal assumptions. However, we only have an efficient algorithm for reconstruction up to affine transformations.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'C', 'url': 'appendix.C', 'start_index': 14}, {'text': 'G', 'url': 'appendix.G', 'start_index': 20}], 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': '890a5c03e154dab1f8d76e3c6b67776f', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: In Appendices C and G, we show that reconstruction is pos- sible up an orthogonal transformation (approximately h2/2 missing parameters, as opposed to h2 for reconstruction up to an affine transformation), and that this is tight under some formal assumptions. However, we only have an efficient algorithm for reconstruction up to affine transformations.

element_id: {'type': 'ListItem', 'element_id': 'bac7e7d6a2b6586df5dc4e702f836a0c', 'text': '5. Extraction Attack for Logit-Bias APIs', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': '890a5c03e154dab1f8d76e3c6b67776f', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'f44dec8f631acb60c95d0fdb4437b136', 'text': 'The above attack makes a significant assumption: that the adversary can directly observe the complete logit vector for each input. In practice, this is not true: no production model we are aware of provides such an API. Instead, for example, they provide a way for users to get the top-K (by logit) token log probabilities. In this section we address this challenge.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 4, 'parent_id': '890a5c03e154dab1f8d76e3c6b67776f', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: The above attack makes a significant assumption: that the adversary can directly observe the complete logit vector for each input. In practice, this is not true: no production model we are aware of provides such an API. Instead, for example, they provide a way for users to get the top-K (by logit) token log probabilities. In this section we address this challenge.

text: Stealing Part of a Production Language Model

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'af2ebb654e615a1b2b5593261a6d3bda', 'text': 'In this section we develop attacks for APIs that return log probabilities for the top K tokens (sorted by logits), and where the user can specify a real-valued bias b ∈ R|X| (the “logit bias”) to be added to the logits for specified tokens before the softmax, i.e.,', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': '698293282932e5fea232266e268113b5', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: In this section we develop attacks for APIs that return log probabilities for the top K tokens (sorted by logits), and where the user can specify a real-valued bias b ∈ R|X| (the “logit bias”) to be added to the logits for specified tokens before the softmax, i.e.,

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '4e5d42ef359e4cda1a447b1fce1e543e', 'text': 'where TopK(z) returns the K highest entries of z ∈ Rl and their indices. Many APIs (prior to this paper) provided such an option for their state-of-the-art models (OpenAI, 2024; Google, 2024). In particular, the OpenAI API supports mod- ifying logits for at most 300 tokens, and the logit bias for each token is restricted to the range [−100,100] (OpenAI, 2023).', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'OpenAI', 'url': 'cite.openai:create-chat-completion', 'start_index': 164}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.openai:create-chat-completion', 'start_index': 172}, {'text': 'Google', 'url': 'cite.google:changelog-1.38.0', 'start_index': 178}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.google:changelog-1.38.0', 'start_index': 186}, {'text': 'OpenAI', 'url': 'cite.openai:logit-bias', 'start_index': 348}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.openai:logit-bias', 'start_index': 356}], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': '49406228a12476c7cf8d2a131ea7c22b', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: where TopK(z) returns the K highest entries of z ∈ Rl and their indices. Many APIs (prior to this paper) provided such an option for their state-of-the-art models (OpenAI, 2024; Google, 2024). In particular, the OpenAI API supports mod- ifying logits for at most 300 tokens, and the logit bias for each token is restricted to the range [−100,100] (OpenAI, 2023).

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '1a8001023c68ced88d26d2f08810253a', 'text': 'All that remains is to show that we can uncover the full logit vector for distinct prompt queries through this API. In this section, we develop techniques for this purpose. Once we have recovered multiple complete logit vector, we can run the attack from Section 4.2 without modification.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4 . 2', 'url': 'subsection.4.2', 'start_index': 263}], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': '49406228a12476c7cf8d2a131ea7c22b', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: All that remains is to show that we can uncover the full logit vector for distinct prompt queries through this API. In this section, we develop techniques for this purpose. Once we have recovered multiple complete logit vector, we can run the attack from Section 4.2 without modification.

element_id: {'type': 'Title', 'element_id': '8a6555636ffc46967608c5a9aa3715f4', 'text': '5.2. Evaluation Methodology', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': '16eebedf72b4c25ea43c2ad7edcb26de', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '4971eaf1aa298a1ba24e7012064aaadc', 'text': 'Practical attacks must be efficient, both to keep the cost of extraction manageable and to bypass any rate limiters or other filters in the APIs. We thus begin with two cost definitions that we use to measure the efficacy of our attack.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': '8a6555636ffc46967608c5a9aa3715f4', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Practical attacks must be efficient, both to keep the cost of extraction manageable and to bypass any rate limiters or other filters in the APIs. We thus begin with two cost definitions that we use to measure the efficacy of our attack.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'a6470a2f19e63b85804e5ca98e764787', 'text': 'Token cost: the number of tokens the adversary sends to (or receives from) the model during the attack. Most APIs charge users per-token, so this metric represents the mone- tary cost of an attack (after scaling by the token cost).', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': '8a6555636ffc46967608c5a9aa3715f4', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Token cost: the number of tokens the adversary sends to (or receives from) the model during the attack. Most APIs charge users per-token, so this metric represents the mone- tary cost of an attack (after scaling by the token cost).

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '26569ffdecf6843bffbcbe095fb5585a', 'text': 'Query cost: the total duration of the attack. Most APIs place a limit on the number of queries an adversary can make in any given interval, and so some attacks may be faster but cost more (by sending more tokens per query).', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': '8a6555636ffc46967608c5a9aa3715f4', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Query cost: the total duration of the attack. Most APIs place a limit on the number of queries an adversary can make in any given interval, and so some attacks may be faster but cost more (by sending more tokens per query).

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '3cff4c3cfd193ba6178f7c085afa12d0', 'text': 'In the remainder of this section we develop several attacks under varying attack assumptions and optimizing for either token cost, query cost, or both.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': '8a6555636ffc46967608c5a9aa3715f4', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: In the remainder of this section we develop several attacks under varying attack assumptions and optimizing for either token cost, query cost, or both.

element_id: {'type': 'Title', 'element_id': '1b84187fbb145841d4760b0604039982', 'text': '5.3. Extraction Attack for Top-5 Logit Bias APIs', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': '16eebedf72b4c25ea43c2ad7edcb26de', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: 5.3. Extraction Attack for Top-5 Logit Bias APIs

text: We develop a technique to compute the logit vector for any prefix p via a sequence of queries with varying logit biases.

By subtracting the bias B and merging answers from all of these queries, we recover the entire logit vector.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': 'f6961ec6b33a0a32807c498ae76a8471', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: with a large enough B. Each query thus promotes five different tokens {k,k + 1,...,k + 4} into the top-5, which allows us to observe their logits. By subtracting the bias B and merging answers from all of these queries, we recover the entire logit vector.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '7ca08e94c405a8bdace1385efffa2e39', 'text': 'Unfortunately, we cannot use this attack directly because all production APIs we are aware of return logprobs (the log of the softmax output of the model) instead of logits. The problem now is that when we apply a logit bias B to the i-th token and observe that token’s logprob, we get the value exp(zj) + exp(zi + B)(cid:1)', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': 'f6961ec6b33a0a32807c498ae76a8471', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Unfortunately, we cannot use this attack directly because all production APIs we are aware of return logprobs (the log of the softmax output of the model) instead of logits. The problem now is that when we apply a logit bias B to the i-th token and observe that token’s logprob, we get the value exp(zj) + exp(zi + B)(cid:1)

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '3e2e6d3cc0dd78bb18bb1cc16800c1e2', 'text': 'i = zi + B − log(cid:0)X yB', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': 'f6961ec6b33a0a32807c498ae76a8471', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

{'type': 'Title', 'element_id': '2b53c096c89d638224c952dd1a95977e', 'text': 'j̸=i', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 5, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '501e8e0f581f7254198ce0982311c900', 'text': 'We thus get an additional bias-dependent term which we need to deal with. We propose two approaches.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': '2b53c096c89d638224c952dd1a95977e', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: We thus get an additional bias-dependent term which we need to deal with. We propose two approaches.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'ed19e8a1fafdf7d23086f26f5aee6e5d', 'text': 'Our first approach relies on a common “reference” token that lets us learn the relative difference between all logits (this is the best we can hope for, since the softmax is invariant under additive shifts to the logits). Suppose the top token for a prompt is R, and we want to learn the relative difference between the logits of tokens i and R. We add a large bias B to token i to push it to the top-5, and then observe the logprobs of both token i and R. We have: R − yB yB', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': '2b53c096c89d638224c952dd1a95977e', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Our first approach relies on a common “reference” token that lets us learn the relative difference between all logits (this is the best we can hope for, since the softmax is invariant under additive shifts to the logits). Suppose the top token for a prompt is R, and we want to learn the relative difference between the logits of tokens i and R. We add a large bias B to token i to push it to the top-5, and then observe the logprobs of both token i and R. We have: R − yB yB

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'dc1bf486b3c2cc18c7a96604a44c0d71', 'text': 'i − B = zR + zi .', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': '2b53c096c89d638224c952dd1a95977e', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '421c4fcf485778f5518744592ed1bb66', 'text': 'Since we can observe 5 logprobs, we can compare the ref- erence token R to four tokens per query, by adding a large bias that pushes all four tokens into the top 5 (along with the reference token). We thus issue a sequence of queries', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': '2b53c096c89d638224c952dd1a95977e', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Since we can observe 5 logprobs, we can compare the ref- erence token R to four tokens per query, by adding a large bias that pushes all four tokens into the top 5 (along with the reference token). We thus issue a sequence of queries

element_id: {'type': 'UncategorizedText', 'element_id': '77b5dcacaee86a80293140291d076a59', 'text': 'O(p,bi = bi+1 = bi+2 = bi+3 = B)', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': '2b53c096c89d638224c952dd1a95977e', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'ef37151e74df8251053ba614e4621a57', 'text': 'for i ∈ {0,4,8,··· ,|X|}. This recovers the logits up to the free parameter zR that we set to 0.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': '2b53c096c89d638224c952dd1a95977e', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: for i ∈ {0,4,8,··· ,|X|}. This recovers the logits up to the free parameter zR that we set to 0.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'd27f6c7ee18719a76fbecf3153e34cf0', 'text': 'Query cost. This attack reveals the value of 4 logits with each query to the model (the fifth being used as a reference point), for a cost of 1/4 queries per logit.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': '2b53c096c89d638224c952dd1a95977e', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Query cost. This attack reveals the value of 4 logits with each query to the model (the fifth being used as a reference point), for a cost of 1/4 queries per logit.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '28fb5d858a61de414d948c55ce0bd9cf', 'text': 'In Appendix E we present a second, more sophisticated method that allows us to recover 5 logits per query, i.e., a cost of 1/5, by viewing each logprob we receive as a linear constraint on the original logits.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'E', 'url': 'appendix.E', 'start_index': 12}], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': '2b53c096c89d638224c952dd1a95977e', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: In Appendix E we present a second, more sophisticated method that allows us to recover 5 logits per query, i.e., a cost of 1/5, by viewing each logprob we receive as a linear constraint on the original logits.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '0b76b48b6da09ec306af89ee15591755', 'text': 'Token cost. Recall that our attack requires that we learn the logits for several distinct prompts; and so each prompt must be at least one token long. Therefore, this attack costs at least two tokens per query (one input and one output), or a cost of 1/2 for each token of output. But, in practice, many models (like gpt-3.5-turbo) include a few tokens of overhead along with every single query. This increases the token cost per logit to 2+∆ 4 where ∆ is the number of overhead tokens; for gpt-3.5-turbo we report ∆ = 7.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 5, 'parent_id': '2b53c096c89d638224c952dd1a95977e', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Token cost. Recall that our attack requires that we learn the logits for several distinct prompts; and so each prompt must be at least one token long. Therefore, this attack costs at least two tokens per query (one input and one output), or a cost of 1/2 for each token of output. But, in practice, many models (like gpt-3.5-turbo) include a few tokens of overhead along with every single query. This increases the token cost per logit to 2+∆ 4 where ∆ is the number of overhead tokens; for gpt-3.5-turbo we report ∆ = 7.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '79f9d634daf5d1d3753af87a32702825', 'text': 'An improved cost-optimal attack. It is possible to gen- eralize the above attack to improve both the query cost and token cost. Instead of issuing queries to the model that reveal 4 or 5 logit values for a single generated token, we might instead hope to be able to send a multi-token query p2 ...pn] and then ask for the logprob vector [p0 for each prefix of the prompt [p0], [p0 p2] etc. OpenAI’s API did allow for queries of this form in the past, by providing logprobs for prompt tokens as well as generated tokens by combining the logprob and echo parameters; this option has since been removed.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': '7fb2fe76acbe02663c9e6a6b0599f2bd', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: An improved cost-optimal attack. It is possible to gen- eralize the above attack to improve both the query cost and token cost. Instead of issuing queries to the model that reveal 4 or 5 logit values for a single generated token, we might instead hope to be able to send a multi-token query p2 ...pn] and then ask for the logprob vector [p0 for each prefix of the prompt [p0], [p0 p2] etc. OpenAI’s API did allow for queries of this form in the past, by providing logprobs for prompt tokens as well as generated tokens by combining the logprob and echo parameters; this option has since been removed.

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '8b1c9074b0f58004775b02ce316e0439', 'text': 'Analysis. It is easy to see that the query cost of this attack is 1 4m, where m is the expansion factor. Further, since each query requires 1 + m tokens, the token cost is 1+m 4m . (Or, 1 + m + ∆ if the API has an overhead of ∆ tokens.) Note that if m = 1, i.e., there is no expansion, this attack reduces to our first attack and the analysis similarly gives a query cost of 1/4 and a token cost of 1/2.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': '0cfda7988e8f764e04994b213ff3fc29', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Analysis. It is easy to see that the query cost of this attack is 1 4m, where m is the expansion factor. Further, since each query requires 1 + m tokens, the token cost is 1+m 4m . (Or, 1 + m + ∆ if the API has an overhead of ∆ tokens.) Note that if m = 1, i.e., there is no expansion, this attack reduces to our first attack and the analysis similarly gives a query cost of 1/4 and a token cost of 1/2.

text: 5.4. Extraction Attack for top-1 Binary Logit Bias APIs

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '40ca74fe2c080976945f092bbdba075b', 'text': 'In light of our attacks, it is conceivable that model providers introduce restrictions on the above API. We now demon- strate that an attack is possible even if the API only returns the top logprob (K = 1 in the API from Section 5.1), and the logit bias is constrained to only take one of two values.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '5 . 1', 'url': 'subsection.5.1', 'start_index': 229}], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': 'd3823630f2664d469b8da93e94728091', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: In light of our attacks, it is conceivable that model providers introduce restrictions on the above API. We now demon- strate that an attack is possible even if the API only returns the top logprob (K = 1 in the API from Section 5.1), and the logit bias is constrained to only take one of two values.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'd01f868f3b80f368f1c0ab7464f42cca', 'text': 'API. We place two following further restrictions on the logit bias API (Section 5.1): first, we set K = 1, and only see the most likely token’s logprob; and second, each logit bias entry b is constrained to be in {−1,0}. These constraints would completely prevent the attacks from the prior section. We believe this constraint is significantly tighter than any practical implementation would define.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '5 . 1', 'url': 'subsection.5.1', 'start_index': 80}], 'page_number': 6, 'parent_id': 'd3823630f2664d469b8da93e94728091', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: API. We place two following further restrictions on the logit bias API (Section 5.1): first, we set K = 1, and only see the most likely token’s logprob; and second, each logit bias entry b is constrained to be in {−1,0}. These constraints would completely prevent the attacks from the prior section. We believe this constraint is significantly tighter than any practical implementation would define.

element_id: {'type': 'Footer', 'element_id': '2a0e40c873006ebc08a35653303226f5', 'text': '6', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 6, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '84340c8211926b5158b3cbf5ec59e021', 'text': 'Method. At first it may seem impossible to be able to learn any information about a token t if it is not already the most likely token. However, note that if we query the model twice, once without any logit bias, and once with a logit bias of −1 for token t, then the top token will be slightly more likely with a bias of −1, with exactly how slight depending on the value of token t’s logprob. Specifically, in Appendix D we show the logprob equals (1/e−1)−1(exp(ytop −y′ top) −1) where ytop and y′ top are the logprobs of the most likely token when querying with logit bias of 0 and −1.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'D', 'url': 'appendix.D', 'start_index': 419}], 'page_number': 6, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Method. At first it may seem impossible to be able to learn any information about a token t if it is not already the most likely token. However, note that if we query the model twice, once without any logit bias, and once with a logit bias of −1 for token t, then the top token will be slightly more likely with a bias of −1, with exactly how slight depending on the value of token t’s logprob. Specifically, in Appendix D we show the logprob equals (1/e−1)−1(exp(ytop −y′ top) −1) where ytop and y′ top are the logprobs of the most likely token when querying with logit bias of 0 and −1.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '19fae726b8fe60aa3842ca33f6ab8c1c', 'text': 'Analysis. This attack requires 1 query and token per logprob extracted. However, as we will show in the evaluation, this attack is much less numerically stable than the previously- discussed attacks, and so may require more queries to reach the same level of accuracy.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 6, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Analysis. This attack requires 1 query and token per logprob extracted. However, as we will show in the evaluation, this attack is much less numerically stable than the previously- discussed attacks, and so may require more queries to reach the same level of accuracy.

element_id: {'type': 'ListItem', 'element_id': '8651aadb04d2ecf6be7dcf38ddc9b611', 'text': '6. Extraction From Logprob-free APIs', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 6, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '2d35458d5a236afde2f9cf4b44e1c896', 'text': 'A more conservative API provider may remove access to the combination of logit bias and logprobs entirely. Indeed, after disclosing our attack to OpenAI, they removed the ability for logit bias to impact the top logprobs—thus preventing the attacks from the prior sections. To exploit situations such at this, we further develop several logprob-free attacks that recover the complete logit vector by performing binary search on the logit bias vector, albeit at increased cost.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 6, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: A more conservative API provider may remove access to the combination of logit bias and logprobs entirely. Indeed, after disclosing our attack to OpenAI, they removed the ability for logit bias to impact the top logprobs—thus preventing the attacks from the prior sections. To exploit situations such at this, we further develop several logprob-free attacks that recover the complete logit vector by performing binary search on the logit bias vector, albeit at increased cost.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'a6b251dd0dfb9105ca981863763fbf2e', 'text': 'Lemma 6.1. element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'd0cb137cadc9addfdfb3a30ca9f1f2a9', 'text': 'This imposes a system of linear constraints on the log- its. By querying the model many times, and accumulat- ing many such systems of equations, we can recover the logit values more efficiently. To do this, we accumulate all such linear constraints in the set C, and at the end of each round, compute the smaller and largest possible values for logiti − logit0 by solving a linear program that maxi- mizes/minimizes this value over the constraint set C. Thus, at each round, we can maintain an interval that encloses logiti − logit0, and refine the interval at each round given additional information from the queries made in that round. After T rounds (where T is chosen based on the total query budget for the attack), we return the tightest known bounds on each logit. Lemma 6.2. Suppose that logiti − logit0 ∈ [−B,0] for all i = 1,...,l. Then, Algorithm 3 returns an interval [αi,βi] such that logiti − logit0 ∈ [αi,βi] for each i such that logiti − logit0 ∈ [−B,0]. By querying the model many times, and accumulat- ing many such systems of equations, we can recover the logit values more efficiently. To do this, we accumulate all such linear constraints in the set C, and at the end of each round, compute the smaller and largest possible values for logiti − logit0 by solving a linear program that maxi- mizes/minimizes this value over the constraint set C. Thus, at each round, we can maintain an interval that encloses logiti − logit0, and refine the interval at each round given additional information from the queries made in that round. After T rounds (where T is chosen based on the total query budget for the attack), we return the tightest known bounds on each logit. Lemma 6.2. Suppose that logiti − logit0 ∈ [−B,0] for all i = 1,...,l. Then, Algorithm 3 returns an interval [αi,βi] such that logiti − logit0 ∈ [αi,βi] for each i such that logiti − logit0 ∈ [−B,0]. element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'cf6d81d3f17a84cba454ccebf2c90722', 'text': 'Proof. Algorithm 3 maintains the invariant that logiti − logit0 ∈ [αi,βi] in each round. We will prove by induction that this is true and that the true vector of logits always lies in C. Note that by the assumption stated in the Lemma, this is clearly true at the beginning of the first round. Sup- pose that this is true after K < T rounds. Then, in the K + 1-th round, the constraints added are all valid con- straints for the true logit vector, since the API returning token k guarantees that logitk + bk ≥ logitj + bj for all j ̸= k. Hence, by induction, the algorithm always ensures that logiti − logit0 ∈ [αi,βi]. In Section 6.2.1, we show the LP to compute αi,βi for all i can be seen as an all-pairs shortest paths problem on graph with edge weights cjk = minrounds bj − bk where the mini- mum is taken over all rounds where the token returned was k. This ensures the computation complexity of maintaining the logit difference intervals is O(N3).', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '3', 'url': 'algorithm.3', 'start_index': 17}, {'text': '6 . 2 . 1', 'url': 'subsubsection.6.2.1', 'start_index': 630}], 'page_number': 8, 'parent_id': '1fcef8d882acc132230e18ead0c26fc6', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Proof. Algorithm 3 maintains the invariant that logiti − logit0 ∈ [αi,βi] in each round. We will prove by induction that this is true and that the true vector of logits always lies in C. Note that by the assumption stated in the Lemma, this is clearly true at the beginning of the first round. Sup- pose that this is true after K < T rounds. Then, in the K + 1-th round, the constraints added are all valid con- straints for the true logit vector, since the API returning token k guarantees that logitk + bk ≥ logitj + bj for all j ̸= k. Hence, by induction, the algorithm always ensures that logiti − logit0 ∈ [αi,βi]. In Section 6.2.1, we show the LP to compute αi,βi for all i can be seen as an all-pairs shortest paths problem on graph with edge weights cjk = minrounds bj − bk where the mini- mum is taken over all rounds where the token returned was k. This ensures the computation complexity of maintaining the logit difference intervals is O(N3).

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '06970d3c0c838015b7a4cb4a3b194726', 'text': 'We can find the distances from 0 to all other vertices using the Bellman-Ford algorithm in O(N3) time. If N = 300, this is at most comparable to the latency of O. Since only N edges of the graph update at each step, we note that the heuristic of just updating and doing a few incremental iterations of Bellman-Ford gets [αi,βi] to high precision in practice. The number of API queries and the token cost, of course, remains the same.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 8, 'parent_id': 'a76cb1772486aeeae0915bc529a13e72', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: We can find the distances from 0 to all other vertices using the Bellman-Ford algorithm in O(N3) time. If N = 300, this is at most comparable to the latency of O. Since only N edges of the graph update at each step, we note that the heuristic of just updating and doing a few incremental iterations of Bellman-Ford gets [αi,βi] to high precision in practice. The number of API queries and the token cost, of course, remains the same.

element_id: {'type': 'Title', 'element_id': '638a2150a384ac86173997884ddb33a6', 'text': 'Hyperrectangles', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 8, 'parent_id': '1fcef8d882acc132230e18ead0c26fc6', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '15c966a4ad9e071419758f295a68463a', 'text': 'The main issue of the previous approach is that some tokens are sampled more often than others, even in the case our prior for the logit vector is uniform over [−B,0]. This is because the "centering of the hyperrectangle" logit bias does not partition the hyperrectangle into equally- sized parts labeled by the argmax coordinate. For exam- ple, if βi − αi ≪ βj − αj, under an uniform prior over [αi,βi] × [αj,βj], j will be much more likely to be the output token than i. Hence, in Algorithm 3 we rarely get constraints lower-bounding logiti in terms of other logits, which makes for weaker relaxations of C.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '3', 'url': 'algorithm.3', 'start_index': 493}], 'page_number': 8, 'parent_id': '638a2150a384ac86173997884ddb33a6', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: The main issue of the previous approach is that some tokens are sampled more often than others, even in the case our prior for the logit vector is uniform over [−B,0]. This is because the "centering of the hyperrectangle" logit bias does not partition the hyperrectangle into equally- sized parts labeled by the argmax coordinate. For exam- ple, if βi − αi ≪ βj − αj, under an uniform prior over [αi,βi] × [αj,βj], j will be much more likely to be the output token than i. Hence, in Algorithm 3 we rarely get constraints lower-bounding logiti in terms of other logits, which makes for weaker relaxations of C.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '8863e031db0ef6e79b9488d64d59ef56', 'text': 'Our solution is to bias tokens so that the output token distri- bution is closer to uniform; in particular, biasing the token with the smallest βt − αt (the 0 token) to have probability exactly 1/(N + 1) given an uniform prior over the hyper- rectangle. One logit bias that satisfies this is:', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 8, 'parent_id': '638a2150a384ac86173997884ddb33a6', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Our solution is to bias tokens so that the output token distri- bution is closer to uniform; in particular, biasing the token with the smallest βt − αt (the 0 token) to have probability exactly 1/(N + 1) given an uniform prior over the hyper- rectangle. One logit bias that satisfies this is:

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'c4bdc3091da27db3b4595c2eec16c3b1', 'text': 'We now run Algorithm 3, with one simple modification: we replace bi = −α+β 2 with b = −(1 − c)α − cβ. As can be seen in Table 3, the modified algorithm outperforms the method in 6.2 significantly.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '3', 'url': 'algorithm.3', 'start_index': 21}, {'text': '3', 'url': 'table.caption.5', 'start_index': 125}, {'text': '6 . 2', 'url': 'subsection.6.2', 'start_index': 176}], 'page_number': 8, 'parent_id': '2399e6289de6dcc5af39c378241f6e8d', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: We now run Algorithm 3, with one simple modification: we replace bi = −α+β 2 with b = −(1 − c)α − cβ. As can be seen in Table 3, the modified algorithm outperforms the method in 6.2 significantly.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'c7ddc2f6e089d4e9ed2f8493b063c899', 'text': 'The goal of balanced sampling of all output tokens can be approached in many ways. For example, we could tune c in the above expression; bias tokens which O hasn’t returned previously to be more likely; or solve for the exact logit bias that separates C (or some relaxation) into equal parts. the queries/logit metric of this method in Table 3 is surprisingly close to optimal.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '3', 'url': 'table.caption.5', 'start_index': 342}], 'page_number': 8, 'parent_id': '2399e6289de6dcc5af39c378241f6e8d', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: The goal of balanced sampling of all output tokens can be approached in many ways. For example, we could tune c in the above expression; bias tokens which O hasn’t returned previously to be more likely; or solve for the exact logit bias that separates C (or some relaxation) into equal parts. the queries/logit metric of this method in Table 3 is surprisingly close to optimal.

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '80d3804a85f4cd3fd800e70d8f5a0058', 'text': 'We now study the efficacy of our practical stealing attack.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': '92c6604d219d7a488e191247510b5dad', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: We now study the efficacy of our practical stealing attack.

element_id: {'type': 'Title', 'element_id': '9a9a0933547f8060cec8b9fa512b192c', 'text': '7.1. Logit Validation', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': '69cef9548744b646820887d44e7eb86d', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'ee734b2d51deb98e4c9f0c7285274d0f', 'text': 'We begin by validating that the attacks developed in the prior sections can effectively recover the full logit vector given a limited query interface. In Table 3 we report the average number of bits of agreement between the true logit vector and the recovered logit vector, as well as the (amortized) number of queries required to recover one full logit vector.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '3', 'url': 'table.caption.5', 'start_index': 160}], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': '9a9a0933547f8060cec8b9fa512b192c', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: We begin by validating that the attacks developed in the prior sections can effectively recover the full logit vector given a limited query interface. In Table 3 we report the average number of bits of agreement between the true logit vector and the recovered logit vector, as well as the (amortized) number of queries required to recover one full logit vector.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'd5531ff1a846d9b6c7004ceed27ad41b', 'text': 'Generally, attacks that operate under stronger threat mod- els have higher precision. But theoretical improvements are not always practical: the theoretically stronger attack from §E that learns 5 logprobs per query in practice re- quires more queries and recovers logits with lower fidelity. This is because this attack is numerically unstable: it re- quires a potentially ill-conditioned matrix, and therefore can require re-querying the API after adjusting the logit bias. Our strongest logprob-free attack is highly efficient, and recovers 18 bits of precision at just 3.7 queries per logit. In Appendix F we theoretically analyze how far this is from optimal, and find it is within a factor of two.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'E', 'url': 'appendix.E', 'start_index': 181}, {'text': 'F', 'url': 'appendix.F', 'start_index': 606}], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': '9a9a0933547f8060cec8b9fa512b192c', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Generally, attacks that operate under stronger threat mod- els have higher precision. But theoretical improvements are not always practical: the theoretically stronger attack from §E that learns 5 logprobs per query in practice re- quires more queries and recovers logits with lower fidelity. This is because this attack is numerically unstable: it re- quires a potentially ill-conditioned matrix, and therefore can require re-querying the API after adjusting the logit bias. Our strongest logprob-free attack is highly efficient, and recovers 18 bits of precision at just 3.7 queries per logit. In Appendix F we theoretically analyze how far this is from optimal, and find it is within a factor of two.

element_id: {'type': 'Title', 'element_id': 'e0ca53cd75803a4aebcd70de9eb61f36', 'text': '7.2. Stealing Parts of Production Models', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': '69cef9548744b646820887d44e7eb86d', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'f6fafb192584544263f5bb6f959c45cf', 'text': 'We now investigate our ability to steal production language models, focusing on five of OpenAI’s models available on 1 January 2024: ada, babbage, babbage-002, gpt-3.5- turbo-instruct, and gpt-3.5-turbo-1106. We selected these models because these were the only production models which were able to receive advance permission to attempt an extraction attack; we are exceptionally grateful to OpenAI for allowing us to perform this research using their models.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': 'e0ca53cd75803a4aebcd70de9eb61f36', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: We now investigate our ability to steal production language models, focusing on five of OpenAI’s models available on 1 January 2024: ada, babbage, babbage-002, gpt-3.5- turbo-instruct, and gpt-3.5-turbo-1106. We selected these models because these were the only production models which were able to receive advance permission to attempt an extraction attack; we are exceptionally grateful to OpenAI for allowing us to perform this research using their models.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'ccdbb1137898d0c404aaa6640c1e86cc', 'text': 'Given the results from the prior section, we chose to imple- ment the improved 4-logprob attack (Section 5.3) because it is both the most query efficient attack and also the most precise attack. Switching to a different attack algorithm would increase our total experiment cost significantly, and so we do not perform these ablation studies.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '5 . 3', 'url': 'subsection.5.3', 'start_index': 105}], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': 'e0ca53cd75803a4aebcd70de9eb61f36', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Given the results from the prior section, we chose to imple- ment the improved 4-logprob attack (Section 5.3) because it is both the most query efficient attack and also the most precise attack. Switching to a different attack algorithm would increase our total experiment cost significantly, and so we do not perform these ablation studies.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'd86f8d2c9ec237b9bbd619e93886fffe', 'text': 'Both our hidden-dimension-stealing and entire-layer- stealing attack worked for all five of these models. The size we recover from the model perfectly matches the ac- tual size of the original model, as confirmed by OpenAI. For the first three models, we report in Table 4 the size we recover because (1) the sizes of these models was never pre- viously confirmed, but (2) they have now been deprecated and so disclosing the size is not harmful. In discussions with OpenAI, we decided to withhold disclosure of the size of gpt-3.5-turbo models, but we confirmed with them that the number our attack reported was accurate.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4', 'url': 'table.caption.7', 'start_index': 268}], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': 'e0ca53cd75803a4aebcd70de9eb61f36', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Both our hidden-dimension-stealing and entire-layer- stealing attack worked for all five of these models. The size we recover from the model perfectly matches the ac- tual size of the original model, as confirmed by OpenAI. For the first three models, we report in Table 4 the size we recover because (1) the sizes of these models was never pre- viously confirmed, but (2) they have now been deprecated and so disclosing the size is not harmful. In discussions with OpenAI, we decided to withhold disclosure of the size of gpt-3.5-turbo models, but we confirmed with them that the number our attack reported was accurate.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'ff4633c8b725085507bdda2586918bf0', 'text': 'When running the full layer-stealing attack, we confirmed that our extracted weights are nearly identical to the ac- tual weights, with error < 7 · 10−4, up to an h × h matrix product as discussed previously. Table 4 reports the RMS between our extracted weight matrix and the actual model weights, after “aligning” the two by an h × h transform.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4', 'url': 'table.caption.7', 'start_index': 214}], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': 'e0ca53cd75803a4aebcd70de9eb61f36', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: When running the full layer-stealing attack, we confirmed that our extracted weights are nearly identical to the ac- tual weights, with error < 7 · 10−4, up to an h × h matrix product as discussed previously. Table 4 reports the RMS between our extracted weight matrix and the actual model weights, after “aligning” the two by an h × h transform.

element_id: {'type': 'ListItem', 'element_id': 'c51cc3924dd356d15b204cda2d534747', 'text': '8. Defenses', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': 'e0ca53cd75803a4aebcd70de9eb61f36', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'ae36ddae373e72b60d1d9b8541c87eb4', 'text': 'It would be possible to prevent or mitigate this attack in a number of different ways, albeit with loss of functionality.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': 'e0ca53cd75803a4aebcd70de9eb61f36', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: It would be possible to prevent or mitigate this attack in a number of different ways, albeit with loss of functionality.

element_id: {'type': 'Title', 'element_id': '7d4c232854f452ec265cd6cbdf792372', 'text': '8.1. Prevention', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': '69cef9548744b646820887d44e7eb86d', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'c5a3df237ae4d259a2a819f1dec6383f', 'text': 'Remove logit bias. Perhaps the simplest defense would be to outright remove the logit bias parameter from the API. Unfortunately, there are several legitimate use cases of this parameter. For example, several works use logit bias in order to perform controlled or constrained generation (Jiang et al., 2023; Yang & Klein, 2021), to shift generation and mimic fine-tuning the model (Liu et al., 2024; Mitchell et al., 2024), or other reasons (Ren et al., 2023; Lee et al., 2022).', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Jiang', 'url': 'cite.jiang2023active', 'start_index': 288}, {'text': 'et al .,', 'url': 'cite.jiang2023active', 'start_index': 294}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.jiang2023active', 'start_index': 302}, {'text': 'Yang & Klein', 'url': 'cite.yang2021fudge', 'start_index': 308}, {'text': '2021', 'url': 'cite.yang2021fudge', 'start_index': 322}, {'text': 'Liu et al .,', 'url': 'cite.liu2024tuning', 'start_index': 381}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.liu2024tuning', 'start_index': 393}, {'text': 'Mitchell et al .,', 'url': 'cite.mitchell2024emulator', 'start_index': 399}, {'text': 'Ren et al .,', 'url': 'cite.ren2023selfevaluation', 'start_index': 441}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.ren2023selfevaluation', 'start_index': 453}, {'text': 'Lee et al .,', 'url': 'cite.lee2022game', 'start_index': 459}, {'text': '2022', 'url': 'cite.lee2022game', 'start_index': 471}], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': '7d4c232854f452ec265cd6cbdf792372', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Remove logit bias. Perhaps the simplest defense would be to outright remove the logit bias parameter from the API. Unfortunately, there are several legitimate use cases of this parameter. For example, several works use logit bias in order to perform controlled or constrained generation (Jiang et al., 2023; Yang & Klein, 2021), to shift generation and mimic fine-tuning the model (Liu et al., 2024; Mitchell et al., 2024), or other reasons (Ren et al., 2023; Lee et al., 2022).

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '07da8b49e5979763855b2f78a7fad6d2', 'text': 'Replace logit bias with a block-list. This would support (some) of the functionality discussed in the prior section, but would still prevent our attack.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': '7d4c232854f452ec265cd6cbdf792372', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Replace logit bias with a block-list. Instead of offering a logit bias, model developers could replace it with a block- list of tokens the model is prohibited from emitting. This would support (some) of the functionality discussed in the prior section, but would still prevent our attack.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '1158fd01c79f662d0d365f0e5ecb7e56', 'text': 'Architectural changes. Instead of modifying the API, we could instead make changes to the model. Our attack only works because the hidden dimension h is less than the output dimension l. This suggests a natural architectural defense: split the final layer into two layers, one that goes from h → t and then t → l where t > l and a nonlinearity was placed in between. This is not very efficient though, as the last linear layer is large (quadratic in the vocabulary size).', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 9, 'parent_id': '7d4c232854f452ec265cd6cbdf792372', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Architectural changes. Instead of modifying the API, we could instead make changes to the model. Our attack only works because the hidden dimension h is less than the output dimension l. This suggests a natural architectural defense: split the final layer into two layers, one that goes from h → t and then t → l where t > l and a nonlinearity was placed in between. This is not very efficient though, as the last linear layer is large (quadratic in the vocabulary size).

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'bfc8439516bb449f0688e0251114a9be', 'text': 'these weights to be small enough to not materially affect the model’s predictions, while also being large enough to look realistic. Then, during the model’s forward pass, we concatenate a vector of random Gaussian noise to the final hidden vector gθ(p) before multiplying by W. Figure 7 shows an example of this, where we expand GPT-2 small to appear as if it was 1024 dimensional instead of 768 di- mensions. This misleads the adversary into thinking that the model is wider than it actually is.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '7', 'url': 'figure.caption.13', 'start_index': 284}], 'page_number': 10, 'parent_id': '8b7e5767422b4ab77dbbb764bceb5e4c', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: these weights to be small enough to not materially affect the model’s predictions, while also being large enough to look realistic. Then, during the model’s forward pass, we concatenate a vector of random Gaussian noise to the final hidden vector gθ(p) before multiplying by W. Figure 7 shows an example of this, where we expand GPT-2 small to appear as if it was 1024 dimensional instead of 768 di- mensions. This misleads the adversary into thinking that the model is wider than it actually is.

element_id: {'type': 'Title', 'element_id': '32c834b820f0df0654e63d09a586e5da', 'text': '8.2. Mitigations', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 10, 'parent_id': '46e6100dd4d783691b8277a0fbc99760', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'bf11b1ba65c34caf52c703b5bc9733c2', 'text': 'Logit bias XOR logprobs. Our attack is 10× cheaper when an adversary can supply both a logit bias and also view output logprobs. This suggests a natural mitigation: prohibit queries to the API that make use of both logit bias and logprobs at the same time. This type of defense is com- mon in both the security and machine learning community: for example, in 2023 OpenAI removed the ability to com- bine both echo and logprobs, but with either alone being allowed; this defense would behave similarly.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 10, 'parent_id': '32c834b820f0df0654e63d09a586e5da', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Logit bias XOR logprobs. Our attack is 10× cheaper when an adversary can supply both a logit bias and also view output logprobs. This suggests a natural mitigation: prohibit queries to the API that make use of both logit bias and logprobs at the same time. This type of defense is com- mon in both the security and machine learning community: for example, in 2023 OpenAI removed the ability to com- bine both echo and logprobs, but with either alone being allowed; this defense would behave similarly.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'ecbcc3642e3f2385a80c15afc4210133', 'text': 'Noise addition. By adding a sufficient amount of noise to the output logits of any given query, it would be possible to prevent our attack. However, logit-noise has the potential to make models less useful. We perform some preliminary experiments on this direction in Appendix H.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'H', 'url': 'appendix.H', 'start_index': 276}], 'page_number': 10, 'parent_id': '32c834b820f0df0654e63d09a586e5da', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Noise addition. By adding a sufficient amount of noise to the output logits of any given query, it would be possible to prevent our attack. However, logit-noise has the potential to make models less useful. We perform some preliminary experiments on this direction in Appendix H.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '52a33ef79e4b50e516047cb9e4235fec', 'text': 'Rate limits on logit bias. Our attack requires that we are able to learn at least h logit values for each prompt p. One defense would be to allow logit-bias queries to the model, but only allow T = ˜h/5 logit bias queries for any given prompt p to prevent an adversary from learning if a model has hidden dimension ˜h or smaller.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 10, 'parent_id': '32c834b820f0df0654e63d09a586e5da', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Rate limits on logit bias. Our attack requires that we are able to learn at least h logit values for each prompt p. One defense would be to allow logit-bias queries to the model, but only allow T = ˜h/5 logit bias queries for any given prompt p to prevent an adversary from learning if a model has hidden dimension ˜h or smaller.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '41afd48c9e9f4703232abc61cb602e40', 'text': 'Unfortunately this has several significant drawbacks: the threshold has to be independent of h (or learning the thresh- old would reveal h); the system would need to maintain state of all user queries to the API; and preventing Sybil attacks requires a global pool of user queries, which can present significant privacy risks (Debenedetti et al., 2023).', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Debenedetti et al .,', 'url': 'cite.debenedetti2023privacy', 'start_index': 325}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.debenedetti2023privacy', 'start_index': 345}], 'page_number': 10, 'parent_id': '32c834b820f0df0654e63d09a586e5da', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Unfortunately this has several significant drawbacks: the threshold has to be independent of h (or learning the thresh- old would reveal h); the system would need to maintain state of all user queries to the API; and preventing Sybil attacks requires a global pool of user queries, which can present significant privacy risks (Debenedetti et al., 2023).

element_id: {'type': 'Footer', 'element_id': '4c44bb52b843c192c776738bb8ebcbfc', 'text': '10', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 10, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'd30d7a6d5c9e404d1e0c6de706178a14', 'text': 'Detect malicious queries. Instead of preventing any queries that might leak model weights, an alternate strategy could be to implement standard anti-abuse tools to detect any patterns of malicious behavior. Several proposals of this form exist for prior machine learning attacks, includ- ing model stealing (Juuti et al., 2019; Pal et al., 2021) and adversarial examples (Chen et al., 2020).', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Juuti et al .,', 'url': 'cite.juuti2019prada', 'start_index': 308}, {'text': '2019', 'url': 'cite.juuti2019prada', 'start_index': 322}, {'text': 'Pal et al .,', 'url': 'cite.pal2021stateful', 'start_index': 328}, {'text': '2021', 'url': 'cite.pal2021stateful', 'start_index': 340}, {'text': 'Chen et al .,', 'url': 'cite.chen2020stateful', 'start_index': 372}, {'text': '2020', 'url': 'cite.chen2020stateful', 'start_index': 385}], 'page_number': 10, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Detect malicious queries. Instead of preventing any queries that might leak model weights, an alternate strategy could be to implement standard anti-abuse tools to detect any patterns of malicious behavior. Several proposals of this form exist for prior machine learning attacks, includ- ing model stealing (Juuti et al., 2019; Pal et al., 2021) and adversarial examples (Chen et al., 2020).
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Juuti et al .,', 'url': 'cite.juuti2019prada', 'start_index': 308}, {'text': '2019', 'url': 'cite.juuti2019prada', 'start_index': 322}, {'text': 'Pal et al .,', 'url': 'cite.pal2021stateful', 'start_index': 328}, {'text': '2021', 'url': 'cite.pal2021stateful', 'start_index': 340}, {'text': 'Chen et al .,', 'url': 'cite.chen2020stateful', 'start_index': 372}, {'text': '2020', 'url': 'cite.chen2020stateful', 'start_index': 385}], 'page_number': 10, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

element_id: {'type': 'ListItem', 'element_id': '28572753a7c09e86296e53518ff781a1', 'text': '9. Future Work', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 10, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '99dda69df0af16754afb7237d8cca0ce', 'text': 'We are motivated to study this problem not because we ex- pect to be able to steal an entire production transformer model bit-for-bit, but because we hope to conclusively demonstrate that model stealing attacks are not just of aca- demic concern but can be practically applied to the largest production models deployed today. We see a number of potential directions for improving on this attack.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 10, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: We are motivated to study this problem not because we ex- pect to be able to steal an entire production transformer model bit-for-bit, but because we hope to conclusively demonstrate that model stealing attacks are not just of aca- demic concern but can be practically applied to the largest production models deployed today. We see a number of potential directions for improving on this attack.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'f5c52306b22d79c0db0d18ecfdcaca39', 'text': 'Breaking symmetry with quantized weights. Large pro- duction models are typically stored “quantized”, where each weight is represented in just 4 or 8 bits. In principle, this quantization could allow an adversary to recover a nearly bit-for-bit copy of the matrix W: while there exist an infi- nite number of matrices W·G, only one will be discretized properly. Unfortunately, this integer-constrained problem is NP-hard in general (similar problems are the foundation for an entire class of public key cryptosystems). But this need not imply that the problem is hard on all instances.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 10, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Breaking symmetry with quantized weights. Large pro- duction models are typically stored “quantized”, where each weight is represented in just 4 or 8 bits. In principle, this quantization could allow an adversary to recover a nearly bit-for-bit copy of the matrix W: while there exist an infi- nite number of matrices W·G, only one will be discretized properly. Unfortunately, this integer-constrained problem is NP-hard in general (similar problems are the foundation for an entire class of public key cryptosystems). But this need not imply that the problem is hard on all instances.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'f0ee017ca378b70578fa1612e3f03a60', 'text': 'Extending this attack beyond a single layer. Our attack recovers a single layer of a transformer. We see no obvious methodology to extend it beyond just a single layer, due to the non-linearity of the models. But we invite further research in this area.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 10, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Extending this attack beyond a single layer. Our attack recovers a single layer of a transformer. We see no obvious methodology to extend it beyond just a single layer, due to the non-linearity of the models. But we invite further research in this area.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'c65b5651e17078bf4bd1cc8bf839e9c3', 'text': 'Removing the logit bias assumption. All our attacks re- quire the ability to pass a logit bias. Model providers includ- ing Google and OpenAI provided this capability when we began the writing of this paper, but this could change. (In- deed, it already has, as model providers begin implementing defenses to prevent this attack.) Other API parameters could', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 10, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Removing the logit bias assumption. All our attacks re- quire the ability to pass a logit bias. Model providers includ- ing Google and OpenAI provided this capability when we began the writing of this paper, but this could change. (In- deed, it already has, as model providers begin implementing defenses to prevent this attack.) Other API parameters could

element_id: {'type': 'Header', 'element_id': '51399bd0a2633dec747b684d67b376d3', 'text': 'Stealing Part of a Production Language Model', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 11, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Stealing Part of a Production Language Model

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '4ec672638b0e6815db1a6fbe4faf408c', 'text': 'give alternative avenues for learning logit information. For example, unconstrained temperature and top-k parame- ters could also leak logit values through a series of queries. In the long run, completely hiding the logit information might be challenging due both to public demand for the feature, and ability of adversaries to infer this information through other means.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 11, 'parent_id': '51399bd0a2633dec747b684d67b376d3', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: give alternative avenues for learning logit information. For example, unconstrained temperature and top-k parame- ters could also leak logit values through a series of queries. In the long run, completely hiding the logit information might be challenging due both to public demand for the feature, and ability of adversaries to infer this information through other means.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'a399dad863e667d3509a6ff5f7c737a7', 'text': 'Exploiting the stolen weights. Recovering a model’s em- bedding projection layer might improve other attacks against that model, e.g., for designing stronger prompt injection attacks or jailbreaks. Alternatively, an attacker could in- fer details about a provider’s finetuning API by observing changes (or the absence thereof) in the last layer. In this paper, we focus primarily on the model extraction problem and leave exploring downstream attacks to future work.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 11, 'parent_id': '51399bd0a2633dec747b684d67b376d3', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Exploiting the stolen weights. Recovering a model’s em- bedding projection layer might improve other attacks against that model, e.g., for designing stronger prompt injection attacks or jailbreaks. Alternatively, an attacker could in- fer details about a provider’s finetuning API by observing changes (or the absence thereof) in the last layer. In this paper, we focus primarily on the model extraction problem and leave exploring downstream attacks to future work.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '97d94bde26c8d1295f8f01c43f121ea3', 'text': 'Practical stealing of other model information. Existing high-fidelity model stealing attacks are “all-or-nothing” at- tacks that recover entire models, but only apply to small ReLU networks. We show that stealing partial information can be much more practical, even for state-of-the-art models. Future work may find that practical attacks can steal many more bits of information about current proprietary models.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 11, 'parent_id': '51399bd0a2633dec747b684d67b376d3', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Practical stealing of other model information. Existing high-fidelity model stealing attacks are “all-or-nothing” at- tacks that recover entire models, but only apply to small ReLU networks. We show that stealing partial information can be much more practical, even for state-of-the-art models. Future work may find that practical attacks can steal many more bits of information about current proprietary models.

element_id: {'type': 'ListItem', 'element_id': 'fa0c5f91b8036a650f323a2985ff5670', 'text': '10. Conclusion', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 11, 'parent_id': '51399bd0a2633dec747b684d67b376d3', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'd4c82ab2075db0f90f10f456fcb6a23f', 'text': 'As the field of machine learning matures, and models tran- sition from research artifacts to production tools used by millions, the field of adversarial machine learning must also adapt. While it is certainly useful to understand the potential applicability of model stealing to three-layer 100-neuron ReLU-only fully-connected networks, at some point it be- comes important to understand to what extent attacks can be actually applied to the largest production models.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 11, 'parent_id': '51399bd0a2633dec747b684d67b376d3', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: As the field of machine learning matures, and models tran- sition from research artifacts to production tools used by millions, the field of adversarial machine learning must also adapt. While it is certainly useful to understand the potential applicability of model stealing to three-layer 100-neuron ReLU-only fully-connected networks, at some point it be- comes important to understand to what extent attacks can be actually applied to the largest production models.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'd133a1d8e9c31f1e45ec0dd22fbe6f43', 'text': 'This paper takes one step in that direction. We give an existence proof that it is possible to steal one layer of a production language model. While there appear to be no immediate practical consequences of learning this layer, it represents the first time that any precise information about a deployed transformer model has been stolen.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 11, 'parent_id': '51399bd0a2633dec747b684d67b376d3', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: This paper takes one step in that direction. We give an existence proof that it is possible to steal one layer of a production language model. While there appear to be no immediate practical consequences of learning this layer, it represents the first time that any precise information about a deployed transformer model has been stolen.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'b4369c824ebbe13a906af3d09f955a7d', 'text': 'Our attack also highlights how small design decisions in- fluence the overall security of a system. Our attack works because of the seemingly-innocuous logit-bias and logprobs parameters made available by the largest machine learning service providers, including OpenAI and Google—although both have now implemented mitigations to prevent this at- tack or make it more expensive. Practitioners should strive to understand how system-level design decisions impact the safety and security of the full product.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 11, 'parent_id': '51399bd0a2633dec747b684d67b376d3', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Our attack also highlights how small design decisions in- fluence the overall security of a system. Our attack works because of the seemingly-innocuous logit-bias and logprobs parameters made available by the largest machine learning service providers, including OpenAI and Google—although both have now implemented mitigations to prevent this at- tack or make it more expensive. Practitioners should strive to understand how system-level design decisions impact the safety and security of the full product.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '647f8b2413ec4fe9e106dfbd903b2176', 'text': 'Overall, we hope our paper serves to further motivate the study of practical attacks on machine learning models, in order to ultimately develop safer and more reliable systems.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 11, 'parent_id': '51399bd0a2633dec747b684d67b376d3', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Overall, we hope our paper serves to further motivate the study of practical attacks on machine learning models, in order to ultimately develop safer and more reliable systems.

element_id: {'type': 'Title', 'element_id': '40392b0480da2c840793feca2883c1eb', 'text': 'A. What’s Going On With GPT-2 Small?', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 14, 'parent_id': 'a915e53129e7e7e0f5a4ea84ae6543b6', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: A. What’s Going On With GPT-2 Small?

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '03b9ff4d5c010b1c5f9b2bf148e3a7d1', 'text': 'Our attack nearly perfectly extracts the model size of all models—except for GPT-2 Small where our extracted size of 757 is off by 11 from the correct 768. Why is this?', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 14, 'parent_id': '40392b0480da2c840793feca2883c1eb', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Our attack nearly perfectly extracts the model size of all models—except for GPT-2 Small where our extracted size of 757 is off by 11 from the correct 768. Why is this?

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '0bba04d0c21ad797eccd73a4036e2584', 'text': 'In Figure 3 we directly inspect this model’s final hidden activation vector across 10,000 different model queries and perform SVD of the resulting activation matrix. We see that despite GPT-2 actually having 768 potential hidden neurons, there are only 757 different activation directions. Thus, while this model is technically a 768 dimensional model, in practice it behaves as if it was a 757 (i.e, the rank of the embedding matrix is 757) dimensional model, and our attack has recovered this effective size.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '3', 'url': 'figure.caption.9', 'start_index': 10}], 'page_number': 14, 'parent_id': '40392b0480da2c840793feca2883c1eb', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: In Figure 3 we directly inspect this model’s final hidden activation vector across 10,000 different model queries and perform SVD of the resulting activation matrix. We see that despite GPT-2 actually having 768 potential hidden neurons, there are only 757 different activation directions. Thus, while this model is technically a 768 dimensional model, in practice it behaves as if it was a 757 (i.e, the rank of the embedding matrix is 757) dimensional model, and our attack has recovered this effective size.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '3bd5f0825cfc3afe3255eff97d80f52b', 'text': 'However, when running the model in higher float64 precision, we find that indeed all dimensions are used, but that the smallest dozen or so singular values are much smaller than the other singular values, an observation made by concurrent work (Cancedda, 2024).', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Cancedda', 'url': 'cite.spectral', 'start_index': 243}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.spectral', 'start_index': 253}], 'page_number': 14, 'parent_id': '40392b0480da2c840793feca2883c1eb', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: However, when running the model in higher float64 precision, we find that indeed all dimensions are used, but that the smallest dozen or so singular values are much smaller than the other singular values, an observation made by concurrent work (Cancedda, 2024).

{'type': 'Title', 'element_id': '2c46e13dfe1e94b32b9ea7a45cb7e9d7', 'text': 'B.1. LayerNorm Does Not Affect Our Rank h Assumption', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 14, 'parent_id': 'a915e53129e7e7e0f5a4ea84ae6543b6', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: B.1. LayerNorm Does Not Affect Our Rank h Assumption

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '939ef58957a57af859aeb8dd395c1fc0', 'text': 'Almost all LLMs that have publicly available architecture details use LayerNorm (Ba et al., 2016) or RMSNorm (Zhang & Sennrich, 2019) just before applying the output projection W (Biderman, 2024). LayerNorm begins with a centering step, which projects its input onto a (h − 1)-dimensional subspace (and RMSNorm does not). In theory, this could break our assumption that the rank of the matrix with columns gθ (pi) (i = 1,...,n) has rank h (Lemma 4.1). In practice, all LLMs we surveyed (Biderman, 2024) enabled the LayerNorm bias, which means the matrices had full rank h (besides GPT-2 Small: see Appendix A).', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Ba et al .,', 'url': 'cite.ba2016layer', 'start_index': 81}, {'text': '2016', 'url': 'cite.ba2016layer', 'start_index': 92}, {'text': 'Zhang &', 'url': 'cite.zhang2019root', 'start_index': 110}, {'text': 'Sennrich', 'url': 'cite.zhang2019root', 'start_index': 118}, {'text': '2019', 'url': 'cite.zhang2019root', 'start_index': 128}, {'text': 'Biderman', 'url': 'cite.stellabidermangooglesheet', 'start_index': 180}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.stellabidermangooglesheet', 'start_index': 190}, {'text': '4 . 1', 'url': 'theorem.4.1', 'start_index': 446}, {'text': 'Biderman', 'url': 'cite.stellabidermangooglesheet', 'start_index': 487}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.stellabidermangooglesheet', 'start_index': 497}, {'text': 'A', 'url': 'appendix.A', 'start_index': 607}], 'page_number': 14, 'parent_id': '2c46e13dfe1e94b32b9ea7a45cb7e9d7', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Almost all LLMs that have publicly available architecture details use LayerNorm (Ba et al., 2016) or RMSNorm (Zhang & Sennrich, 2019) just before applying the output projection W (Biderman, 2024). LayerNorm begins with a centering step, which projects its input onto a (h − 1)-dimensional subspace (and RMSNorm does not). In theory, this could break our assumption that the rank of the matrix with columns gθ (pi) (i = 1,...,n) has rank h (Lemma 4.1). In practice, all LLMs we surveyed (Biderman, 2024) enabled the LayerNorm bias, which means the matrices had full rank h (besides GPT-2 Small: see Appendix A).
