element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'c60282769b1d0b6b1987696672f059e8', 'text': 'A.1 Linear Recurrent Models Recently, to address the computational cost of Transformers in both training and inference, linear recurrent models have attracted much attention (Tiezzi et al. 2024), mainly due to their fast inference and training. The first generation of models–such as RetNet (Yutao Sun et al. 2023), LRU (Orvieto et al. 2023), RWKV (Peng, Alcaide, et al. 2023), S5 (J. T. Smith, Warrington, and Linderman 2023), and S4 (Gu, Goel, and Re 2022)–uses data-independent transition matrix/decay mechanism. The second generation of such models started to incorporate gating mechanism, a widely used techniques in traditional RNNs (Gers, Jürgen Schmidhuber, and Cummins 2000; Greff et al. 2016; Van Der Westhuizen and Lasenby 2018), into such linear architectures–e.g., Griffin (De et al. 2024), SSMs (Behrouz, Santacatterina, and Zabih 2024; Dao and Gu 2024; Gu and Dao 2024; Hasani et al. 2023), RWKV6 (Peng, Goldstein, et al. 2024). The third generation of linear recurrent models are based on more complex memory updating rule based on meta-learning, online learning, and/or delta-rule, resulting in more expressive and effective models such as: Longhorn (B. Liu et al. 2024), Gated DeltaNet (S. Yang, Kautz, and Hatamizadeh 2024), TTT (Yu Sun et al. 2024), and DeltaNet (S. Yang, B. Wang, Yu Zhang, et al. 2024). Our LMM model can be seen as the next generation of such models, in which we incorporate the token flow into the memory updating mechanism, having more powerful memory updating process. See Appendix C for a detailed discussion of different recurrent models and Titans.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@tiezzi2024resurgence', 'start_index': 189}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.0@sun2023retentive', 'start_index': 308}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.0@orvieto2023resurrecting', 'start_index': 335}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.0@peng2023rwkv', 'start_index': 370}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.0@smith2023simplified', 'start_index': 420}, {'text': '2022', 'url': 'cite.0@gu2022efficiently', 'start_index': 452}, {'text': '2000', 'url': 'cite.0@gers2000learning', 'start_index': 677}, {'text': '2016', 'url': 'cite.0@greff2016lstm', 'start_index': 695}, {'text': '2018', 'url': 'cite.0@van2018unreasonable', 'start_index': 732}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@de2024griffin', 'start_index': 793}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@behrouz2024mambamixer', 'start_index': 841}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@dao2024transformers', 'start_index': 858}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@gu2024mamba', 'start_index': 875}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.0@hasani2023liquid', 'start_index': 895}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@peng2024eagle', 'start_index': 933}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@liu2024longhorn', 'start_index': 1177}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@yang2024gated', 'start_index': 1232}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@sun2024learning', 'start_index': 1258}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@yang2024parallelizing', 'start_index': 1314}, {'text': 'Appendix C', 'url': 'appendix.C', 'start_index': 1510}], 'page_number': 25, 'parent_id': 'a23c743a726a422fba0de2e7e95fb90a', 'filename': '2501.00663v1.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: A.1 Linear Recurrent Models Recently, to address the computational cost of Transformers in both training and inference, linear recurrent models have attracted much attention (Tiezzi et al. 2024), mainly due to their fast inference and training. The first generation of models–such as RetNet (Yutao Sun et al. 2023), LRU (Orvieto et al. 2023), RWKV (Peng, Alcaide, et al. 2023), S5 (J. T. Smith, Warrington, and Linderman 2023), and S4 (Gu, Goel, and Re 2022)–uses data-independent transition matrix/decay mechanism. The second generation of such models started to incorporate gating mechanism, a widely used techniques in traditional RNNs (Gers, Jürgen Schmidhuber, and Cummins 2000; Greff et al. 2016; Van Der Westhuizen and Lasenby 2018), into such linear architectures–e.g., Griffin (De et al. 2024), SSMs (Behrouz, Santacatterina, and Zabih 2024; Dao and Gu 2024; Gu and Dao 2024; Hasani et al. 2023), RWKV6 (Peng, Goldstein, et al. 2024). The third generation of linear recurrent models are based on more complex memory updating rule based on meta-learning, online learning, and/or delta-rule, resulting in more expressive and effective models such as: Longhorn (B. Liu et al. 2024), Gated DeltaNet (S. Yang, Kautz, and Hatamizadeh 2024), TTT (Yu Sun et al. 2024), and DeltaNet (S. Yang, B. Wang, Yu Zhang, et al. 2024). Our LMM model can be seen as the next generation of such models, in which we incorporate the token flow into the memory updating mechanism, having more powerful memory updating process. See Appendix C for a detailed discussion of different recurrent models and Titans.

element_id: {'type': 'Title', 'element_id': '95b19082f3d631a0136e7e3012adcef1', 'text': 'A.2 Transformer-based Architectures', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 25, 'filename': '2501.00663v1.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}

{'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '4557a3c184a0bbf90f7340d3258eb52a', 'text': 'Transformers. Transformers (Vaswani et al. 2017) as the de facto backbone for many deep learning models are based on attention mechanism (Bahdanau 2014). They, however, suffer from quadratic computational cost, limiting their ability to scale to long context window. To improve the memory consumption and throughput of softmax attention for longer sequences, various studies focused on I/O aware implementations of attention (Dao 2024; Dao, D. Fu, et al. 2022), designing more efficient attention mechanisms by sparsifying the attention matrix (B. Chen et al. 2021; Choromanski et al. 2021; Dai et al. 2019; J. Dong et al. 2024; Roy et al. 2021), approximating the softmax (Arora et al. 2024), or developing kernel-based (linear) attentions (Aksenov et al. 2024; Kacham, Mirrokni, and P. Zhong 2024; Schlag, Irie, and Jürgen Schmidhuber 2021; S. Yang, B. Wang, Shen, et al. 2024).', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '2017', 'url': 'cite.0@transformers', 'start_index': 43}, {'text': '2014', 'url': 'cite.0@bahdanau2014neural', 'start_index': 147}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@dao2024flashattention', 'start_index': 429}, {'text': '2022', 'url': 'cite.0@flashattention-1', 'start_index': 454}, {'text': '2021', 'url': 'cite.0@chen2021scatterbrain', 'start_index': 557}, {'text': '2021', 'url': 'cite.0@choromanski2021rethinking', 'start_index': 582}, {'text': '2019', 'url': 'cite.0@dai2019transformerxl', 'start_index': 599}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@dong2024flex', 'start_index': 620}, {'text': '2021', 'url': 'cite.0@roy2021efficient', 'start_index': 637}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@arora2024simple', 'start_index': 684}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@aksenov2024linear', 'start_index': 754}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@kacham2024polysketchformer', 'start_index': 791}, {'text': '2021', 'url': 'cite.0@schlag2021linear', 'start_index': 834}], 'page_number': 25, 'parent_id': '95b19082f3d631a0136e7e3012adcef1', 'filename': '2501.00663v1.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Transformers. Transformers (Vaswani et al. 2017) as the de facto backbone for many deep learning models are based on attention mechanism (Bahdanau 2014). They, however, suffer from quadratic computational cost, limiting their ability to scale to long context window. To improve the memory consumption and throughput of softmax attention for longer sequences, various studies focused on I/O aware implementations of attention (Dao 2024; Dao, D. Fu, et al. 2022), designing more efficient attention mechanisms by sparsifying the attention matrix (B. Chen et al. 2021; Choromanski et al. 2021; Dai et al. 2019; J. Dong et al. 2024; Roy et al. 2021), approximating the softmax (Arora et al. 2024), or developing kernel-based (linear) attentions (Aksenov et al. 2024; Kacham, Mirrokni, and P. Zhong 2024; Schlag, Irie, and Jürgen Schmidhuber 2021; S. Yang, B. Wang, Shen, et al. 2024).

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '31d84d4b4bacd64e86d15698ec4ceb8e', 'text': 'Segment-based Transformers. Another line of research to improve the efficiency of Transformers is segment-based or Chunk Transformers (Dai et al. 2019). The main drawback of chunk Transformers is that segments are fully separated and so the context window is limited to the length of the chunks. To address this issue, various studies discuss the importance of a memory so it can help the model to transfer information across chunks (Bulatov, Yuri Kuratov, et al. 2023; Bulatov, Yury Kuratov, and Burtsev 2022; Feng et al. 2022; Hutchins et al. 2022; Rodkin et al. 2024; Z. Wang et al. 2019; Q. Wu et al. 2020; Zancato et al. 2024). The key differences of Titans with these models are: (1) The memory in such models are simple small size vectors, lacking expressive power to compress complex information; (2) The memory module lacks forget mechanism, leading to a fast memory overflow; (3) only focus on momentary surprise, missing the information flow. More specifically, recalling Recurrent Memory Transformers (RMT) (Bulatov, Yuri Kuratov, et al. 2023; Bulatov, Yury Kuratov, and Burtsev 2022; Rodkin et al. 2024), one can treat Titans (MAC) as the generalization of RMT, where we use a neural memory module instead of a vector-valued small size memory.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '2019', 'url': 'cite.0@dai2019transformerxl', 'start_index': 144}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.0@bulatov2023scaling', 'start_index': 462}, {'text': '2022', 'url': 'cite.0@bulatov2022recurrent', 'start_index': 503}, {'text': '2022', 'url': 'cite.0@feng2022learn', 'start_index': 521}, {'text': '2022', 'url': 'cite.0@hutchins2022block', 'start_index': 543}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@rodkin2024associative', 'start_index': 563}, {'text': '2019', 'url': 'cite.0@wang2019r', 'start_index': 584}, {'text': '2020', 'url': 'cite.0@wu2020memformer', 'start_index': 603}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@zancato2024bmojo', 'start_index': 624}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.0@bulatov2023scaling', 'start_index': 1044}, {'text': '2022', 'url': 'cite.0@bulatov2022recurrent', 'start_index': 1085}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@rodkin2024associative', 'start_index': 1105}], 'page_number': 25, 'parent_id': '95b19082f3d631a0136e7e3012adcef1', 'filename': '2501.00663v1.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Segment-based Transformers. Another line of research to improve the efficiency of Transformers is segment-based or Chunk Transformers (Dai et al. 2019). The main drawback of chunk Transformers is that segments are fully separated and so the context window is limited to the length of the chunks. To address this issue, various studies discuss the importance of a memory so it can help the model to transfer information across chunks (Bulatov, Yuri Kuratov, et al. 2023; Bulatov, Yury Kuratov, and Burtsev 2022; Feng et al. 2022; Hutchins et al. 2022; Rodkin et al. 2024; Z. Wang et al. 2019; Q. Wu et al. 2020; Zancato et al. 2024). The key differences of Titans with these models are: (1) The memory in such models are simple small size vectors, lacking expressive power to compress complex information; (2) The memory module lacks forget mechanism, leading to a fast memory overflow; (3) only focus on momentary surprise, missing the information flow. More specifically, recalling Recurrent Memory Transformers (RMT) (Bulatov, Yuri Kuratov, et al. 2023; Bulatov, Yury Kuratov, and Burtsev 2022; Rodkin et al. 2024), one can treat Titans (MAC) as the generalization of RMT, where we use a neural memory module instead of a vector-valued small size memory.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'c4edf9d974e2a7313eb0dd14192e944c', 'text': 'Memory for Large Language Models. Another interesting research direction has been to incorporate external memory modules to LLMs after training (Z. He et al. 2024; Khandelwal et al. 2020; Y. Wang, Y. Gao, et al. 2024). Such models are different from our approach as we incorporate the memory as a part of initial architecture and so we train it in an end-to-end manner. Also, most of these explicit memory modules suffer from the same limitations as chunk-based Transformers (mentioned above). For a detailed discussion of such models, we refer to the recent study of Y. Wang, Han, et al. (2024).', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@he2024camelot', 'start_index': 158}, {'text': '2020', 'url': 'cite.0@Khandelwal2020Generalization', 'start_index': 182}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@wang2024memoryllm', 'start_index': 212}], 'page_number': 25, 'parent_id': '95b19082f3d631a0136e7e3012adcef1', 'filename': '2501.00663v1.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Memory for Large Language Models. Another interesting research direction has been to incorporate external memory modules to LLMs after training (Z. He et al. 2024; Khandelwal et al. 2020; Y. Wang, Y. Gao, et al. 2024). Such models are different from our approach as we incorporate the memory as a part of initial architecture and so we train it in an end-to-end manner. Also, most of these explicit memory modules suffer from the same limitations as chunk-based Transformers (mentioned above). For a detailed discussion of such models, we refer to the recent study of Y. Wang, Han, et al. (2024).

{'type': 'Title', 'element_id': 'ec73933ac8248ef90145a62a83535713', 'text': 'A.3 Test Time Training and Fast Weight Programs', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 26, 'filename': '2501.00663v1.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: A.3 Test Time Training and Fast Weight Programs

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'bfa8a390148606502d4a07bb2816ec46', 'text': 'Memory Design and Augmentation with Memory. In the literature, a substantial research effort have been toward designing memory modules that are capable of either memorizing the knowledge abstraction (e.g., persistent mem- ory) (Sukhbaatar, Grave, et al. 2019), or memorizing the data-dependent information (also known as contextual memory), through recurrence (Bulatov, Yury Kuratov, and Burtsev 2022; Rodkin et al. 2024; Zancato et al. 2024), Transformers (Berges et al. 2024; Cetin et al. 2024; Feng et al. 2022; Le, Tran, and Venkatesh 2020; Munkhdalai, Faruqui, and Gopal 2024; J. Zhang et al. 2024), gradient (Irie, Csordás, and Jürgen Schmidhuber 2022; Munkhdalai, Sordoni, et al. 2019), or other learning paradigms (Sukhbaatar, Weston, Fergus, et al. 2015; Weston, Chopra, and Bordes 2014). These memory models, however, either (1) are based on momentary surprise, missing the data flow and events, (2) lack forget mechanisms to remove the memory, leading to a fast memory overflow (3) are fixed-size shallow (matrix valued) memory, resulting in poor performance in long context, and (4) are based on fixed parameters at test time, lacking test time adaption.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '2019', 'url': 'cite.0@sukhbaatar2019augmenting', 'start_index': 253}, {'text': '2022', 'url': 'cite.0@bulatov2022recurrent', 'start_index': 395}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@rodkin2024associative', 'start_index': 415}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@zancato2024bmojo', 'start_index': 436}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@berges2024memory', 'start_index': 471}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@cetin2024evolved', 'start_index': 490}, {'text': '2022', 'url': 'cite.0@feng2022learn', 'start_index': 508}, {'text': '2020', 'url': 'cite.0@le2020self', 'start_index': 538}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@munkhdalai2024leave', 'start_index': 575}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@zhang2024memory', 'start_index': 597}, {'text': '2022', 'url': 'cite.0@irie2022dual', 'start_index': 652}, {'text': '2019', 'url': 'cite.0@munkhdalai2019metalearned', 'start_index': 686}, {'text': '2015', 'url': 'cite.0@sukhbaatar2015end', 'start_index': 757}, {'text': '2014', 'url': 'cite.0@weston2014memory', 'start_index': 790}], 'page_number': 26, 'parent_id': 'ec73933ac8248ef90145a62a83535713', 'filename': '2501.00663v1.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Memory Design and Augmentation with Memory. In the literature, a substantial research effort have been toward designing memory modules that are capable of either memorizing the knowledge abstraction (e.g., persistent mem- ory) (Sukhbaatar, Grave, et al. 2019), or memorizing the data-dependent information (also known as contextual memory), through recurrence (Bulatov, Yury Kuratov, and Burtsev 2022; Rodkin et al. 2024; Zancato et al. 2024), Transformers (Berges et al. 2024; Cetin et al. 2024; Feng et al. 2022; Le, Tran, and Venkatesh 2020; Munkhdalai, Faruqui, and Gopal 2024; J. Zhang et al. 2024), gradient (Irie, Csordás, and Jürgen Schmidhuber 2022; Munkhdalai, Sordoni, et al. 2019), or other learning paradigms (Sukhbaatar, Weston, Fergus, et al. 2015; Weston, Chopra, and Bordes 2014). These memory models, however, either (1) are based on momentary surprise, missing the data flow and events, (2) lack forget mechanisms to remove the memory, leading to a fast memory overflow (3) are fixed-size shallow (matrix valued) memory, resulting in poor performance in long context, and (4) are based on fixed parameters at test time, lacking test time adaption.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'd2059827adc00ad43ae783f7089239c4', 'text': 'Fast Weight Programs. The idea of seeing linear layers as the key-value (associative) memory system backs to fast weight programs, in which dynamic fast programs are incorporated into recurrent neural networks to serve as writable memory (Schlag, Irie, and Jürgen Schmidhuber 2021; JH Schmidhuber 1992; Jürgen Schmidhuber 1993). The two learning rules of Hebbian (Hebb 2005) and delta (Prados and Kak 1989) are the most popular learning rules for fast weight programs, which have been extensively explored in various studies (Irie, Schlag, et al. 2021; Munkhdalai, Sordoni, et al. 2019; Munkhdalai and H. Yu 2017; Schlag, Irie, and Jürgen Schmidhuber 2021; JH Schmidhuber 1992; S. Yang, Kautz, and Hatamizadeh 2024; S. Yang, B. Wang, Yu Zhang, et al. 2024). All these models, however, are based on momentary surprise, missing the token flow in the sequences (see Section 3.1), and most of them lacks a forgetting gate, resulting in a poor memory management.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '2021', 'url': 'cite.0@schlag2021linear', 'start_index': 276}, {'text': '1992', 'url': 'cite.0@schmidhuber1992learning', 'start_index': 297}, {'text': '1993', 'url': 'cite.0@schmidhuber1993reducing', 'start_index': 322}, {'text': '2005', 'url': 'cite.0@hebb2005organization', 'start_index': 369}, {'text': '1989', 'url': 'cite.0@prados1989neural', 'start_index': 401}, {'text': '2021', 'url': 'cite.0@irie2021going', 'start_index': 547}, {'text': '2019', 'url': 'cite.0@munkhdalai2019metalearned', 'start_index': 581}, {'text': '2017', 'url': 'cite.0@munkhdalai2017neural', 'start_index': 608}, {'text': '2021', 'url': 'cite.0@schlag2021linear', 'start_index': 651}, {'text': '1992', 'url': 'cite.0@schmidhuber1992learning', 'start_index': 672}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@yang2024gated', 'start_index': 710}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@yang2024parallelizing', 'start_index': 751}, {'text': 'Section 3 . 1', 'url': 'subsection.3.1', 'start_index': 862}], 'page_number': 26, 'parent_id': 'ec73933ac8248ef90145a62a83535713', 'filename': '2501.00663v1.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Fast Weight Programs. The idea of seeing linear layers as the key-value (associative) memory system backs to fast weight programs, in which dynamic fast programs are incorporated into recurrent neural networks to serve as writable memory (Schlag, Irie, and Jürgen Schmidhuber 2021; JH Schmidhuber 1992; Jürgen Schmidhuber 1993). The two learning rules of Hebbian (Hebb 2005) and delta (Prados and Kak 1989) are the most popular learning rules for fast weight programs, which have been extensively explored in various studies (Irie, Schlag, et al. 2021; Munkhdalai, Sordoni, et al. 2019; Munkhdalai and H. Yu 2017; Schlag, Irie, and Jürgen Schmidhuber 2021; JH Schmidhuber 1992; S. Yang, Kautz, and Hatamizadeh 2024; S. Yang, B. Wang, Yu Zhang, et al. 2024). All these models, however, are based on momentary surprise, missing the token flow in the sequences (see Section 3.1), and most of them lacks a forgetting gate, resulting in a poor memory management.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '4e0465ef94883879fa17c61398678e1e', 'text': 'Test Time Training. The key ideas of learning at test time or learning to learn (i.e., (Andrychowicz et al. 2016)) backs to very early studies on local learning Bottou and Vapnik 1992, in which each test data sample is trained on its neighbors before making a prediction (Gandelsman et al. 2022; H. Zhang et al. 2006). This approach further has shown promising performance in vision tasks (Jain and Learned-Miller 2011; Mullapudi et al. 2019), mostly due to their ability to mitigate out-of-distribution samples. The most similar studies to ours in this direction are MNM (Munkhdalai, Sordoni, et al. 2019) and TTT-layer (Yu Sun et al. 2024), which we discussed the key differences in Appendix C.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '2016', 'url': 'cite.0@andrychowicz2016learning', 'start_index': 108}, {'text': '1992', 'url': 'cite.0@bottou1992local', 'start_index': 179}, {'text': '2022', 'url': 'cite.0@gandelsman2022test', 'start_index': 290}, {'text': '2006', 'url': 'cite.0@zhang2006svm', 'start_index': 312}, {'text': '2011', 'url': 'cite.0@jain2011online', 'start_index': 414}, {'text': '2019', 'url': 'cite.0@mullapudi2019online', 'start_index': 437}, {'text': '2019', 'url': 'cite.0@munkhdalai2019metalearned', 'start_index': 601}], 'page_number': 26, 'parent_id': 'ec73933ac8248ef90145a62a83535713', 'filename': '2501.00663v1.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Test Time Training. The key ideas of learning at test time or learning to learn (i.e., (Andrychowicz et al. 2016)) backs to very early studies on local learning Bottou and Vapnik 1992, in which each test data sample is trained on its neighbors before making a prediction (Gandelsman et al. 2022; H. Zhang et al. 2006). This approach further has shown promising performance in vision tasks (Jain and Learned-Miller 2011; Mullapudi et al. 2019), mostly due to their ability to mitigate out-of-distribution samples. The most similar studies to ours in this direction are MNM (Munkhdalai, Sordoni, et al. 2019) and TTT-layer (Yu Sun et al. 2024), which we discussed the key differences in Appendix C.

element_id: {'type': 'ListItem', 'element_id': 'b560c5ff19505d05699a86f0066b65dc', 'text': 'Momentum-based Rule: The Delta Rule is based on momentary surprise, meaning that the flow of tokens cannot affect the memory update rule. LMM, however, is based on a momentum rule, which consider both past and momentary surprise.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 27, 'filename': '2501.00663v1.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Momentum-based Rule: The Delta Rule is based on momentary surprise, meaning that the flow of tokens cannot affect the memory update rule. LMM, however, is based on a momentum rule, which consider both past and momentary surprise.

element_id: {'type': 'ListItem', 'element_id': 'd9d039363721334f8f092c677f1eaa0a', 'text': 'Deep Memory: While Gated DeltaNet is limited to a linear (matrix-valued) memory as it requires finding the closed recurrence form, LMM allows using deep memory module by using a gradient-based formulation, resulting in higher expressive power.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 27, 'filename': '2501.00663v1.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Deep Memory: While Gated DeltaNet is limited to a linear (matrix-valued) memory as it requires finding the closed recurrence form, LMM allows using deep memory module by using a gradient-based formulation, resulting in higher expressive power.

element_id: {'type': 'ListItem', 'element_id': 'cb0ae5fd5f98e25d319245d231a9614c', 'text': 'Non-Linear Recurrence: While DeltaNet and Gated DeltaNet are based on linear recurrence, our LMM is using inter-chunk non-linear recurrence and intra-chunk linear recurrence. This design allows LMM having a higher expressive power.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 27, 'filename': '2501.00663v1.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Non-Linear Recurrence: While DeltaNet and Gated DeltaNet are based on linear recurrence, our LMM is using inter-chunk non-linear recurrence and intra-chunk linear recurrence. This design allows LMM having a higher expressive power.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '3476e8f92cc26e3416dafc0d13d1e71e', 'text': 'LMM is Generalized TTT Layer. To the best of our knowledge, TTT (Yu Sun et al. 2024), is the only modern linear recurrent models with a gradient-based updating rule. In addition to different architectural designs and also objective functions, our LMM has three key differences with presented TTT layers (Yu Sun et al. 2024):', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@sun2024learning', 'start_index': 79}], 'page_number': 27, 'parent_id': '0da77fba07e5589769fae4b25e633efb', 'filename': '2501.00663v1.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: LMM is Generalized TTT Layer. To the best of our knowledge, TTT (Yu Sun et al. 2024), is the only modern linear recurrent models with a gradient-based updating rule. In addition to different architectural designs and also objective functions, our LMM has three key differences with presented TTT layers (Yu Sun et al. 2024):

element_id: {'type': 'ListItem', 'element_id': '4b4e33f91dc81f12f2a85971d770caa1', 'text': '1. Forgetting Mechanism: TTT layers are updating memory at each time, without having the chance to forget the past data. Accordingly, when fixing the memory size, the model cannot manage the memory for long sequences. A forget mechanism, such as LMM’s, allows clearing the memory when very past information is not needed anymore. We show that in a general case, this forget mechanism is equivalent to weight decay and provide a fast method to incorporate it into the parallel training.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 27, 'parent_id': '0da77fba07e5589769fae4b25e633efb', 'filename': '2501.00663v1.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: 1. Forgetting Mechanism: TTT layers are updating memory at each time, without having the chance to forget the past data. Accordingly, when fixing the memory size, the model cannot manage the memory for long sequences. A forget mechanism, such as LMM’s, allows clearing the memory when very past information is not needed anymore. We show that in a general case, this forget mechanism is equivalent to weight decay and provide a fast method to incorporate it into the parallel training.

element_id: {'type': 'ListItem', 'element_id': '8237325c1d377d14edded24501cbe20c', 'text': '2. Momentum-based Update Rule: TTT layers are based on momentary surprise, meaning that the flow of tokens cannot affect the memory update rule. LMM, however, is based on a momentum rule, which consider both past and momentary surprise. See Section 3.1 for the motivation of this design.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 27, 'parent_id': '0da77fba07e5589769fae4b25e633efb', 'filename': '2501.00663v1.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: 2. Momentum-based Update Rule: TTT layers are based on momentary surprise, meaning that the flow of tokens cannot affect the memory update rule. LMM, however, is based on a momentum rule, which consider both past and momentary surprise. See Section 3.1 for the motivation of this design.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': 'd3c0583ff2875f25f4ba891885d1e3bd', 'text': 'To the best of our knowledge, our neural long-term memory module is the first linear recurrent model with momentum- based update rule.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 27, 'parent_id': '0da77fba07e5589769fae4b25e633efb', 'filename': '2501.00663v1.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: To the best of our knowledge, our neural long-term memory module is the first linear recurrent model with momentum- based update rule.

element_id: {'type': 'NarrativeText', 'element_id': '7547eef799f9b1c06b2b02060045205a', 'text': 'Finally, as a key difference with all the above and other recent linear recurrent studies, note that the hybrid variants of modern linear models–such as Griffin (De et al. 2024), DeltaNet (S. Yang, B. Wang, Yu Zhang, et al. 2024), Gated DeltaNet (S. Yang, Kautz, and Hatamizadeh 2024), H3 (D. Y. Fu et al. 2023), Mamba2 (Dao and Gu 2024), Samba (Ren et al. 2024), etc.–all are based on sequential layer-wise design. We present Titans to show how effectively one can incorporate such memory modules into an architecture.', 'metadata': {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@de2024griffin', 'start_index': 169}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@yang2024parallelizing', 'start_index': 221}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@yang2024gated', 'start_index': 276}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.0@fu2023hungry', 'start_index': 303}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@dao2024transformers', 'start_index': 329}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.0@ren2024samba', 'start_index': 354}], 'page_number': 27, 'parent_id': '0da77fba07e5589769fae4b25e633efb', 'filename': '2501.00663v1.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}}
text: Finally, as a key difference with all the above and other recent linear recurrent studies, note that the hybrid variants of modern linear models–such as Griffin (De et al. 2024), DeltaNet (S. Yang, B. Wang, Yu Zhang, et al. 2024), Gated DeltaNet (S. Yang, Kautz, and Hatamizadeh 2024), H3 (D. Y. Fu et al. 2023), Mamba2 (Dao and Gu 2024), Samba (Ren et al. 2024), etc.–all are based on sequential layer-wise design. We present Titans to show how effectively one can incorporate such memory modules into an architecture.
